Posts.Content: Hi brewcrews If your dad's Gleason score is 6 I don't think there is any chance it has metastasized, and if metastasis was suspected there is no way they would do AS. I don't know what the weight loss could be, for me and most men PC is asymptomatic. Try not to worry. Your dad is going to be fine.
Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Older brother had DaVinci in 2011 PSA 4.1 at diagnosis (had been up and down in 3s for years) Biopsy at UMass Worcester May 2015. Five of 13 cores positive, three 3+3, one 3+4. one 4+3 No perineural invasion. Da Vinci surgery at Brigham & Women's Boston on Aug. 6, 2015 Nerves taken on left, spared on right Catheter out in 7 days Pathology show tumors on both sides, all reclassified 3+4 Stage T2C NO Focally present tumor on right posterior zone (doc thinks it is nothing) Lymphocele infection on August 29 required five day re-hospitalization and drain insertion. Drain in until Sept. 18 Virtually no incontinence Some ED, switch to sildenafil produced great results. Follow up PSA test on Sept. 9, Dec. 10 and March 5 all <0.02. Test at different clinics on Aug. 26, 2016 0.01, on Feb. 6 2017, <0.01, on July 31, 2017 0.01. "The days my gratitude exceeds my expectations, well, I have really good days" ~ Ray Wylie Hubbard
Posts.Title: Dads biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: That's great, Wishbone. Not to rain on your parade but be careful. My wife and I had sex three and a half weeks post op. I was not very firm but good enough for penetration and I did have a dry orgasm which I thought we pretty awesome (like shooting an air rifle.) Later that day I was hitting some flop shots in my yard when I developed an infected lymphocele that made me shake violently with pain and put me back in the hospital for five days. Now I'm home with a drain in my belly. Apparently the lymphoceles are somewhat common post op (undefined sacks of fluid in your abdomen esp. if lymph nodes are dissected). Infections are not as common but can be deadly. The PA for my surgeon said she didn't know if the exertion of sex contributed to the infection or not but she basically told me to do nothing physically till this is resolved. No golf. No work. No sex. No fun.

Posts.Title: Dads biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Hello TMCM, Sorry about your report, brother, but remember biopsies are not definitive on Gleason levels. True, that means they could be worse, but they also can be better. In my case both UMass and Brigham and Women's said my biopsy slides contained some 3+3, 3+4 and 4+3, but when I had the surgery the pathology report classified everything at 3+4. I have no opinion about surgery vs. radiation but if you do have surgery you will find out exactly what Gleason levels yours are. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New Member, Many Questions,Central Pa.

Posts.Content: I live in Massachusetts. I'm 63 and I am married, a father and grandfather. I still work as a high school teacher. I was diagnosed in May, 2015. I am pretty fit, play a lot of golf, tend a huge garden and cut and split about six chords of firewood each year. For four years my primary care doctor had urged me to get a biopsy because my PSA fluctuated between 3 and 5 and my older brother had prostate cancer in 2011. My urologist, an older doctor, kept saying I didn't need one because my PSA would not go up and down if I had PC. He would do a digital exam and send me on my way. He was the same doctor who operated on me for testicular cancer in 1989 and I trusted him. He finally retired. His replacement on my first visit said I didn't need a biopsy (PSA 3) but when my PSA went to 4.1 told me to have one. Five cores of 13 were cancerous -- three 6s and two 7s (one 4+3). That doctor at UMASS-Worcester did not do robotic surgery but that is what I wanted after everything that I read -- plus my brother and my lead guitar player had robotic and were happy with it. The UMASS doctor acted pissed when I told him I was going with Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Dana Farber in Boston, but, hey, it's my life. One good thing about living near Boston--besides the New England Patriots--is great healthcare. I had the surgery Aug. 6, five days ago. I came home the next day. I'm a little sore where the punctures are and the catheter sucks but other than that -- and a little anxiety -- I don't feel bad. I make sure I walk around with my bag in a bucket and take stool softener and laxatives and have had no problems evacuating. I was worried about that because my brother ended up back in the hospital for eight days because he couldn't pass gas. Once he farted, they sent him home. Dr. Kibel said he took some extra from the left side and from the top because it looked "suspicious" but he thinks he got it all. He took the nerve on the left so my sex life could be in trouble. but he said I had a great uretha "stump" so he is confident about incontinence issues. The pathology report will take about a week. I have my fingers crossed. Today, five days after surgery, my left hip hurts. Has anyone else had that? I am wondering if it is because of the way they hang you during the operations and that I am just feeling it now because the anesthesia is wearing off. They gave me some Oxycontin but I hesitate to take that.
Posts.Title: Robotic surgery in Beantown--now my hip hurts

Posts.Content: It just steadily gets better, Bernard. You'll feel better tomorrow and than you'll feel even better the next day. Your path report is a lot like mine. Even though I had a rare complication after a few weeks, I was back in front of my classroom, playing golf, and playing with my band in a couple months. Now, 11 months later, I almost feel like I never had the operation. The ED issue was the longest problem but thanks to Viagra/Cialis and a little hair elastic that is pretty much solved. Time is on your side as the Rolling Stones once pointed out. Good luck.

Posts.Title: DaVinci RP Post-Surgery Update and Pathology Report

Posts.Content: I had the DaVinci surgery 17 days ago and I feel fine but a little tired still. That is getting better. My tiredness is due more to not sleeping well than to the surgery. I was pretty bruised up in my belly and genitals from the surgery but the bruising disappeared quickly. After my diagnosis, a doctor at UMASS tried to convince me conventional sugery was just as good as robotic but everything I read and heard--my brother and my best friend both had robotic in 2011--told me otherwise. There is less blood loss and quicker recovery with robotic. I found that very attractive. Living near Boston I decided to go with the best and had Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Dana Farber and Brigham and Women's, do the surgery on Aug. 6. I was out of the hospital the next day. So far so good. My recovery is going great. Just a little incontinence when I cough or laugh and ED shows growing signs that it will not be a problem. I had a consult with a UMASS radiation doc and an oncologist before I made my decision and even the radiologist said surgery was the best option for me. He said if the surgery doesn't get it all you can use radiation but the reverse is not always true. Good luck, brother.

Posts.Title: Dads biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: I live in Massachusetts. I'm 63 and I am married, a father and grandfather. I still work as a high school teacher. I was diagnosed in May, 2015. I am pretty fit, play a lot of golf, tend a huge garden and cut and split about six chords of firewood each year. For four years my primary care doctor had urged me to get a biopsy because my PSA fluctuated between 3 and 5 and my older brother had prostate cancer in 2011. My urologist, an older doctor, kept saying I didn't need one because my PSA would not go up and down if I had PC. He would do a digital exam and send me on my way. He was the same doctor who operated on me for testicular cancer in 1989 and I trusted him. He finally retired. His replacement on my first visit said I didn't need a biopsy (PSA 3) but when my PSA went to 4.1 told me to have one. Five cores of 13 were cancerous -- three 6s and two 7s (one 4+3). That doctor at UMASS-Worcester did not do robotic surgery but that is what I wanted after everything that I read -- plus my brother and my lead guitar player had robotic and were happy with it. The UMASS doctor acted pissed when I told him I was going with Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Dana Farber in Boston, but, hey, it's my life. One good thing about living near Boston--besides the New England Patriots--is great healthcare. I had the surgery Aug. 6, five days ago. I came home the next day. I'm a little sore where the punctures are and the catheter sucks but other than that -- and a little anxiety -- I don't feel bad. I make sure I walk around with my bag in a bucket and take stool softener and laxatives and have had no problems evacuating. I was worried about that because my brother ended up back in the hospital for eight days because he couldn't pass gas. Once he farted, they sent him home. Dr. Kibel said he took some extra from the left side and from the top because it looked "suspicious" but he thinks he got it all. He took the nerve on the left so my sex life could be in trouble. but he said I had a great uretha "stump" so he is confident about incontinence issues. The pathology report will take about a week. I have my fingers crossed. Today, five days after surgery, my left hip hurts. Has anyone else had that? I am wondering if it is because of the way they hang you during the operations and that I am just feeling it now because the anesthesia is wearing off. They gave me some Oxycontin but I hesitate to take that.

Posts.Content: I had the DaVinci surgery 17 days ago and I feel fine but a little tired still. That is getting better. My tiredness is due more to not sleeping well than to the surgery. I was pretty bruised up in my belly and genitals from the surgery but the bruising disappeared quickly. After my diagnosis, a doctor at UMASS tried to convince me conventional sugery was just as good as robotic but everything I read and heard--my brother and my best friend both had robotic in 2011--told me otherwise. There is less blood loss and quicker recovery with robotic. I found that very attractive. Living near Boston I decided to go with the best and had Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Dana Farber and Brigham and Women's, do the surgery on Aug. 6. I was out of the hospital the next day. So far so good. My recovery is going great. Just a little incontinence when I cough or laugh and ED shows growing signs that it will not be a problem. I had a consult with a UMASS radiation doc and an oncologist before I made my decision and even the radiologist said surgery was the best option for me. He said if the surgery doesn't get it all you can use radiation but the reverse is not always true. Good luck, brother.

Posts.Content: It just steadily gets better, Bernard. You'll feel better tomorrow and than you'll feel even better the next day. Your path report is a lot like mine. Even though I had a rare complication after a few weeks, I was back in front of my classroom, playing golf, and playing with my band in a couple months. Now, 11 months later, I almost feel like I never had the operation. The ED issue was the longest problem but thanks to Viagra/Cialis and a little hair elastic that is pretty much solved. Time is on your side as the Rolling Stones once pointed out. Good luck.

Posts.Content: I had one side of nerves taken too. In just a few weeks I was getting erections that were kind of like water balloons on Cialis (20mg) but they didn't get any firmer in four months. My doc's assistant recommended I switch to Viagra. I did and...Viva Viagra! Thanks to a tip from Michigan Man 16 on this forum I got a prescription from LUEA Pharmacy in Michigan for 90 tabs of 20 mg generic Viagra (sidenafil) for 55 bucks. I don't know if it was the switch or just that I am five months post op but I am a happy camper. My wife is too. Strong like bull!

Posts.Title: WooHoo for the < sign!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate PVD, How did you get generic Viagra in the USA? Pfizer's patent has been extended until 2020. What I did was bring my USA prescription to a walk-in clinic while in Canada, and asked them to re-write the rx for their minimum visit fee of $39. Got 30 100mg tablets of generic sidenafil for about $140 at a Costco there. Then use a simple pill splitter to cut them into quarters. I think that it would cost me over $600 to get the same rx here in the states. My prescription for Viagra was going to cost $48 PER PILL at CVS. I posted something about that and Michigan Man 16 responded that he had used LUEA pharmacy in Swartz Creek,MI with great satisfaction. I called LUEA and they said I needed my P.A. to call in a prescription for 20 mg Sildenafil since that is the only dose they carried. She called for 90 pills and it was just $55 including shipping and I had it in three days. I called it generic Viagra because I understand sildenafil is the active ingredient. Like I said, I don't know if it was the switch from Cialis or time or a combo, but it's working! I don't know if it is cool to put the phone number in (if it's not Highlander can edit it out and you can send me a private message.) The number is 810-635-3355.

Got 30 100mg tablets of generic sidenafil for about $140 at a Costco there. Then use a simple pill splitter to cut them into quarters. I think that it would cost me over $600 to get the same rx here in the states. My prescription for Viagra was going to cost $48 PER PILL at CVS. I posted something about that and Michigan Man 16 responded that he had used LUEA pharmacy in Swartz Creek,MI with great satisfaction. I called LUEA and they said I needed my P.A. to call in a prescription for 20 mg Sildenafil since that is the only dose they carried. She called for 90 pills and it was just $55 including shipping and I had it in three days. I called it generic Viagra because I understand sildenafil is the active ingredient. Like I said, I don't know if it was the switch from Cialis or time or a combo, but it's working! I don't know if it is cool to put the phone number in (if it's not Highlander can edit it out and you can send me a private message.) The number is 810-635-3355.
Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Older brother had DaVinci in 2011 PSA 4.1 at diagnosis (had been up and down in 3s for years) Biopsy at UMass Worcester May 2015. Five of 13 cores positive, three 3+3, one 3+4. one 4+3 No perineural invasion. Da Vinci surgery at Brigham & Women's Boston on Aug. 6, 2015 Nerves taken on left, spared on right Catheter out in 7 days Pathology show tumors on both sides, all reclassified 3+4 Stage T2C NO Focally present tumor on right posterior zone (doc thinks it is nothing) Lymphocele infection on August 29 required five day re-hospitalization and drain insertion. Drain in until Sept. 18 Virtually no incontinence Some ED, switch to sildenafil produced great results. Follow up PSA test on Sept. 9, Dec. 10 and March 5 all <0.02. Test at different clinics on Aug. 26, 2016 0.01, on Feb. 6 2017, <0.01, on July 31, 2017 0.01. "The days my gratitude exceeds my expectations, well, I have really good days" ~ Ray Wylie Hubbard
Posts.Title: Sex and PC

Posts.Content: I had one side of nerves taken too. In just a few weeks I was getting erections that were kind of like water balloons on Cialis (20mg) but they didn't get any firmer in four months. My doc's assistant recommended I switch to Viagra. I did and...Viva Viagra! Thanks to a tip from Michigan Man 16 on this forum I got a prescription from LUEA Pharmacy in Michigan for 90 tabs of 20 mg generic Viagra (sidenafil) for 55 bucks. I don't know if it was the switch or just that I am five months post op but I am a happy camper. My wife is too. Strong like bull!

Posts.Title: Update from Manchester

Posts.Content: It gets better with time. I had the surgery in August and only recently did the leakage stop completely. The erections get better too. They are still not like when I was 18 but they are pretty stiff and getting better. A switch to generic Viagra seemed to help. I don't know if there is any way to speed up the process. One thing on the pee front is to make sure you completely void your bladder before any stimulation.

Posts.Title: Update from Manchester

Posts.Content: That's great. Zero Club is good to belong to. My surgeon at Dana Farber had me do a PSA at one month. I mentioned to him that the Walsh book said it was too early and he said he knows Dr. Walsh and disagrees with him. I also had one at four months. Both <0.02 . I think the one month check is worthwhile if for no other reason than it's nice to hear "undetectable."

Posts.Title: Second Post-op PSA

Posts.Content: Hi FLA, Sorry to hear about your diagnosis but glad to hear it is G6. I just had the robotic surgery a couple weeks ago. That is the way most guys go now, I think. Make sure you get a second opinion. Your insurance should cover everything. After my biopsy, my urologist at UMass had me meet with a radiologist and an oncologist there. I also had an MRI and bone scan and a cardio stress test. On my own, I requested a second opinion from Dr. Adam Kibel, the head of urology at the Dana Farber Clinic and Brigham and Women's Hospital. (One of the great things about living in Massachusetts is that Boston, in addition to being the home of great sports team, is world famous for health care). Again, insurance covers pretty much everything. I figured go to the best. All the doctors love doing surgery, btw, so choose one that has done whatever you decide on doing 100s of times. I chose having Dr. Kibel do the DaVinci robotic surgery. My wife and I took a planned vacation in Yellowstone after the pre-op testing and I came back and he did it. Five hour surgery and I went home the next day. The anesthesia takes a while to leave the body and I felt pretty beat up for a week but the small incisions are almost healed up and the bruising is gone now. The catheter sucked, no other way to put it, but luckily it was out after 7 days. It's been 17 days since my surgery and I feel close to great. I'm still a little incontinent but not too bad, mostly just a little squirt here and there. Based on early results I don't think ED will be a problem. I haven't slept that well overall (I keep feeling like I have to pee) but other than that, no great problems. Good luck, man. This website has been a great resource for me, both for support and getting/sharing information.

Posts.Title: Happy

Posts.Content: Hi Osh, Ditto on the blood. I also had the same thing with my bladder/urethra contracting when I stopped peeing. It was almost painful. Now, 47 days post surgery, that has eased up. I've been lucky with incontinence. Other than one night--when I dreamed about peeing and woke up in a wet bed--I have been totally dry at night. The downside for me is that I still wake up every two hours to urinate. I don't have to pee nearly so often during the day. I sometimes feel a little squirt when I laugh, sneeze or cough but most of the time nothing or almost nothing actually comes out. I had the same problem with the pads and ended up just not wearing them. I've had to change my jockey shorts a couple of times since but the pads drove me nuts and the little ones for women were worse than the bigger ones for men. When I was using pads I found Depends Guards for men to be the best but they all still produced an red itchy scrotum. I used jock itch cream to relieve the itch.

Posts.Title: Questions for the forum experts

Posts.Content: I am hoping for a good report tomorrow --obviously the PSA is tantamount--but I think the drain is going to be in for some time. Walsh doesn't mention lymphoceles in his book, but I talked to a radiologist at Brigham & Women's today and she said most guys who get them have the drain in for at least four weeks. Has anyone else on this forum had one?

Posts.Title: Big day tomorrow

Posts.Content: I had my DaVinci surgery on August 6. Tomorrow I have an appointment with my surgeon and he wants me to have a PSA test before we meet. I don't mind saying both my wife and I are anxious because of the single focal point in my pathology report. My surgeon said it is probably nothing but in the next breath mentions that radiation could be used if it poses a threat. Also, I am just sick of this. I have never been one to sit around and relax. I like to teach. I like to golf, I like to play with my band and i like to garden. I like to be able to pick up my grandkids. I like to take my tractor into the woods and cut down trees, then split, haul and stack firewood. Unfortunately I can't do any of those things. I still have a drain in my belly for an infected lymphocele and have to measure its output every hour or so. It has to get down to 10ccs per day but it is going down slowly (still up in the 100s). That could mean another procedure. I know I need to be patient but patience is a virtue that I don't possess. I'm hoping that (a) the PSA tomorrow is 0, (b) the lymphocele resolves and I can get this damned drain out, and (c) I wake up and I'm 25 years old again. I know a lot of guys on here have had rougher trips but I just ran into a wall of frustrations. Spending five days in the hospital last week made me realize how much I don''t want to deal with this anymore.

Posts.Title: Big day tomorrow

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by petah Hi Kate, I agree with the statements above. Also, take a look at the following article about positive margins: http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr..._cancer410.php That is a a good read, petah. KDB, after my surgery in August I was nervous because pathology revealed a tiny positive margin, a "focal point." My surgeon said he was sure it was nothing. He explained that when the robot squeezes the prostate to take it out it sometimes squeezes the cancer near the edge. I was still nervous despite his reassurance but I have had three PSA test since and they all came back as undetectable. Tell your old man he'll be fine. In a couple weeks he's going to want to go out and play nine.

Posts.Title: Big day tomorrow

Posts.Content: I too had tiny bits of cancer at a margin, a "focally present tumor", but my doc said then he was 100 percent sure it was nothing. He explained that what happens is the robot squeezes the prostate when it pulls it out and thus can squeeze some PC to the edge. So far he's been right--still less than 0.02 on PSA tests 14 months later.

Posts.Title: 2 questions guys.....

Posts.Content: I am hoping for a good report tomorrow --obviously the PSA is tantamount--but I think the drain is going to be in for some time. Walsh doesn't mention lymphoceles in his book, but I talked to a radiologist at Brigham & Women's today and she said most guys who get them have the drain in for at least four weeks. Has anyone else on this forum had one?

Posts.Title: Cialis cost confusion?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman PDV, I did ok, but did not have your experience. At my worst, i went through 2 pads a day, that lasted about a week or two (dont remember, and i'm happy about that), and was wearing nothing within 5 weeks. But i do have a friend who was fully continent from almost the moment that the catheter was pulled out, so indeed, its possible, and congratulations to you. Re the golf thing - i was worried about the same thing. I played golf for the first time about 5 months after surgery. Lo and behold, i gripped it, and ripped it, but i didnt drip it at all. I thought about wearing a shield just in case, but decided to be brave and i walked off the 18th green dry as a bone. I didnt even pee until the 5th hole, then went into the woods twice after that. That was truly a great day for me. I hope you won your match!

Posts.Title: Near total continence 8 days post op--is this possible?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by petah Hi Kate, I agree with the statements above. Also, take a look at the following article about positive margins: http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr..._cancer410.php That is a a good read, petah. KDB, after my surgery in August I was nervous because pathology revealed a tiny positive margin, a "focal point." My surgeon said he was sure it was nothing. He explained that when the robot squeezes the prostate to take it out it sometimes squeezes the cancer near the edge. I was still nervous despite his reassurance but I have had three PSA test since and they all came back as undetectable. Tell your old man he'll be fine. In a couple weeks he's going to want to go out and play nine.

Posts.Title: Post-op questions

Posts.Content: I too had tiny bits of cancer at a margin, a "focally present tumor", but my doc said then he was 100 percent sure it was nothing. He explained that what happens is the robot squeezes the prostate when it pulls it out and thus can squeeze some PC to the edge. So far he's been right--still less than 0.02 on PSA tests 14 months later.

Posts.Title: 2 questions guys.....

Posts.Content: I don't know about Cialis but you can get a prescription for sildenafil (generic Viagra) from your doc and then get it filled at a local family pharmacy. The chains will charge you an arm and a leg but local pharmacies will do it for around $60 for 90 pills (20 mg each.) I find it works better than Cialis. I started off taking five tabs at a time but now I just take two and it's like I am 18 again.

Posts.Title: Cialis cost confusion?

Posts.Content: I just had DaVinci surgery eight days ago on Aug. 6. I had the catheter pulled yesterday. My surgeon, Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Brigham and Women's, said I had a great uretha stump post op and that he was confident about my continence. I was dribbling quite a bit when I got home from the catheter removal yesterday. I put on a new diaper last night and woke up twice to pee. Both times, and this morning, the diaper was totally dry. I've emptied my bladder twice this morning--I've found I can stop and start it with a kegal--and I am almost too ecstatic because I feel like I am almost totally continent eight days after surgery. Has anyone else had a similar experience?

Posts.Title: Near total continence 8 days post op--is this possible?

Posts.Content: I am one year out and just getting back to stiffer erections with generic Viagra (sildenafil) and/or Cialis. One absolute keys is that you have to take Viagra on an empty stomach or it doesn't work. And it works pretty fast with a small (two hours?) window of opportunity. The other key is I use a hair elastic like a cock ring. That really helps because it allows the blood to flow in but not out. A third key is to have a really patient wife and --this may sound too graphic for some--but you have to take care of her first because if you do you don't need to be hard like an iron bar. Happy wife, happy sex life. Paraphrasing a lyric from Little Charlie and the Nightcats, you can lick this problem by using your head.

Posts.Title: new to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi jaybee All is good. No positive margins is great. I had total continence after a month or so and ED is almost gone after one year. I feel now like the operation never happened and your husband will too. The big thing is every three months or so he'll get a PSA test and if it is undetectable you'll have a reason to celebrate. I tell everyone that you feel better one day and then even better the next. The Da Vinci operation beats the hell out of you--did you know he was upside down for a lot of it?--and the anesthesia stays in your body for weeks. Hang in there.

Posts.Title: So freaked out - have we made the wrong decision? (and is this normal?)...

Posts.Content: Hi jaybee All is good. No positive margins is great. I had total continence after a month or so and ED is almost gone after one year. I feel now like the operation never happened and your husband will too. The big thing is every three months or so he'll get a PSA test and if it is undetectable you'll have a reason to celebrate. I tell everyone that you feel better one day and then even better the next. The Da Vinci operation beats the hell out of you--did you know he was upside down for a lot of it?--and the anesthesia stays in your body for weeks. Hang in there.
Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Older brother had DaVinci in 2011 PSA 4.1 at diagnosis (had been up and down in 3s for years) Biopsy at UMass Worcester May 2015. Five of 13 cores positive, three 3+3, one 3+4. one 4+3 No perineural invasion. Da Vinci surgery at Brigham & Women's Boston on Aug. 6, 2015 Nerves taken on left, spared on right Catheter out in 7 days Pathology show tumors on both sides, all reclassified 3+4 Stage T2C NO Focally present tumor on right posterior zone (doc thinks it is nothing) Lymphocele infection on August 29 required five day re-hospitalization and drain insertion. Drain in until Sept. 18 Virtually no incontinence Some ED, switch to sildenafil produced great results. Follow up PSA test on Sept. 9, Dec. 10 and March 5 all <0.02. Test at different clinics on Aug. 26, 2016 0.01, on Feb. 6 2017, <0.01, on July 31, 2017 0.01. "The days my gratitude exceeds my expectations, well, I have really good days" ~ Ray Wylie Hubbard

Posts.Title: The journey begins.

Posts.Content: I was petrified of surgery. Hell, I was even petrified of the biopsy. Turns out the biopsy wasn't that bad and neither was the surgery. I ran into a rare complication, otherwise I would have been back to work in three weeks. Even with the complication--an infected lymphocele which is so rare that only one guy on this forum had ever heard of it--I am now 5 months post surgery and 100 percent back to normal. No incontinence and just a tad of ED, but even the ED has been straightened out with Viagra. My older brother had the surgery in 2011 and is also 100 percent back. One thing your old man should do is get at least one second opinion. I bet his insurance will cover it. I talked to several specialists and surgeons before deciding to have robotic surgery. A radiologist told me I would not be a good candidate for the seeds because my prostate is too small and the radiation would have a negative effect on my urethra. I ended up deciding on Da Vinci surgery with Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Brigham & Women's and the world renown Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. If you're in Connecticut you aren't that far from Boston and I only stayed in the hospital one night.

Posts.Title: Update on my cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Prowler Can you provide the online pharmacy web address for the rest of us? Luea Pharmacy, LTC Inc. 8021 Miller Road Swartz Creek, Michigan 48473 810 635 3355 I got this contact from Michigan Man 16 and it is legit. The first time I used it the price was $57 for 90 tabs of 20 mg sidenafil. The second time was $63. Your doc has to call in the prescription or send it. then you have to call and pay with a credit card. The pills arrive in just a couple days. I take five tabs at once. The only drawback with sidenafil is you have to take it on an empty stomach and it worked best within a couple hours. When I took Cialis pre-surgery it produced oak-like wood for three days. But I'll take birch now! Paul

Posts.Title: The journey begins.

Posts.Content: I dreaded having a biopsy because my brother, who had Davinci surgery in 2011, told me it was the most painful thing he had ever experienced. So even though my primary care guy kept telling me I should have one (PSA up and down in 3s and 4s for two years), when my old school urologist would do a DRE and say I didn't need one, I was relieved. He finally retired and my new urologist said I should have one. I did--and it wasn't that bad. It only took a few minutes and felt like an elastic snapping off my prostate 13 times. Uncomfortable, but I'd say not even a 5 on a pain scale of 10. Other than having a little tube sticking out of my ass with a smoking hot nurse standing there watching, it wasn't bad at all. Unfortunately, or maybe fortunately, five cores were positive and I had the operation on Aug. 6.

Posts.Title: 20 month PSA results are in ......

Posts.Content: Hello Chiguy Definitely get a second opinion. After my biopsy at UMAss revealed I had PC I met with an oncologist and radiologist there and heard about my options. I then made an appointment with Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Dana Farrber/Brigham and Women's in Boston, figuring I might as well hear from the best. If nothing else, you get a second (and actually fourth and fifth) set of eyes on your results. Insurance should pay for pretty much everything. AS was not an option for me at Gleason 4+3 (changed post op to 3+4) nor was radiation a great option since I had radiation following testicular cancer when I was 35, and, more importantlyy, my prostate was small and the radiologist said the seeds could thus cause permanent damage to my urethra. I chose DaVinci and I thought it went great. I was almost totally continent and even had sex with my wife at 3 weeks. I was planning to go back to work in four weeks before a complication from surgery, an infected lymphocele, hit me like a ton of bricks. I am still dealing with that with a drain in my belly but hopefully that will resolve soon. I am going to Boston for my first post op meeting and PSA test today. AS is scary but this whole thing is scary. You'll see on this great forum how everyone post op gets PSA anxiety every three or six months, however often they get tested. Good luck. And tell the Black Hawks to leave some Stanley Cups for the rest of us.

I chose DaVinci and I thought it went great. I was almost totally continent and even had sex with my wife at 3 weeks. I was planning to go back to work in four weeks before a complication from surgery, an infected lymphocele, hit me like a ton of bricks. I am still dealing with that with a drain in my belly but hopefully that will resolve soon. I am going to Boston for my first post op meeting and PSA test today. AS is scary but this whole thing is scary. You'll see on this great forum how everyone post op gets PSA anxiety every three or six months, however often they get tested. Good luck. And tell the Black Hawks to leave some Stanley Cups for the rest of us.

Posts.Content: I used Cialis even before I had PC to make sure each mission was successful. Great stuff and I got it for free from a buddy with PC who somehow was able to get a copious amount every month through his insurance company. Once I had my PC surgery, the Cialis worked but not great. My doc's assistant had me switch to Viagra and the results are better. I also got the address of a legit online pharmacy that sells generic Viagra (sidenafil) cheaply (90 pills of 20 mg for 63 bucks). You need to have your doc call them with a prescription.

Posts.Title: Time,,Tic Toc, Tic Toc

Posts.Content: Hi Kevin The best advice I can give is don't rush it. You'll feel better every day and start to think you are 100 percent, but then the next day you'll feel even better. I ran into a helluva rare complication, an infected lymphocele, after three weeks that put me back in the hospital for five days and on a stomach drain for almost a month. I don't know if that was because I was rushing back to my job as a high school teacher or just a coincidence but just take it slow. Paul

Posts.Title: Time,,Tic Toc, Tic Toc

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=SeaCock;313637]PDV What was the contact info again for the pharmacy in Canada? It is actually in Michigan. You need to have your doc or PA call in a prescription for Sildenafil (generic Viagra) and then you have to call and give them your credit card. Sixty three bucks for 90 20mg tabs. I take five at a time. They send it out that day. It is the LUEA Pharmacy and the number is 810-635-3355. The sildenafil works great as long as you have sex within a couple of hours. Cialis, which last longer, does not have a generic twin yet and is really expensive. I have a friend, though, who gets it for $3 per 100 mg pill with his insurance and he gives me some. I like to combine small does (ex: a third of Cialis with two 20 mg sildenafil) to expand the window of opportunity.

Posts.Title: Erectile Function - should I get my hopes up?

Posts.Content: Hi Delta I am at 11 months and things keep getting better. I woke up with morning wood today! I am using Cialis and/or generic Viagra with pretty good results and that is getting better too. I had a problem with pee coming out during "dry" orgasms but that stopped a couple of months ago. The best tip I can give you is to use a little hair elastic like a cock ring. That definitely helps getting it up and keeping it up. My wife is a lot younger than me too and it is frustrating but the only thing that heals the nerves is time. Good luck.

Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Older brother had DaVinci in 2011 PSA 4.1 at diagnosis (had been up and down in 3s for years) Biopsy at UMass Worcester May 2015. Five of 13 cores positive, three 3+3, one 3+4. one 4+3 No perineural invasion. Da Vinci surgery at Brigham & Women's Boston on Aug. 6, 2015 Nerves taken on left, spared on right Catheter out in 7 days Pathology show tumors on both sides, all reclassified 3+4 Stage T2C NO Focally present tumor on right posterior zone (doc thinks it is nothing) Lymphocele infection on August 29 required five day re-hospitalization and drain insertion. Drain in until Sept. 18 Virtually no incontinence Some ED, switch to sildenafil produced great results. Follow up PSA test on Sept. 9, Dec. 10 and March 5 all <0.02. Test at different clinics on Aug. 26, 2016 0.01, on Feb. 6 2017, <0.01, on July 31, 2017 0.01. "The days my gratitude exceeds my expectations, well, I have really good days" ~ Ray Wylie Hubbard
Posts.Title: Fifteen hours to go....

Posts.Content: Hi Delta I am at 11 months and things keep getting better. I woke up with morning wood today! I am using Cialis and/or generic Viagra with pretty good results and that is getting better too. I had a problem with pee coming out during "dry" orgasms but that stopped a couple of months ago. The best tip I can give you is to use a little hair elastic like a cock ring. That definitely helps getting it up and keeping it up. My wife is a lot younger than me too and it is frustrating but the only thing that heals the nerves is time. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Erectile Function - should I get my hopes up?

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=SeaCock;313637]PDV What was the contact info again for the pharmacy in Canada? It is actually in Michigan. You need to have your doc or PA call in a prescription for Sildenafil (generic Viagra) and then you have to call and give them your credit card. Sixty three bucks for 90 20mg tabs. I take five at a time. They send it out that day. It is the LUEA Pharmacy and the number is 810-635-3355. The sildenafil works great as long as you have sex within a couple of hours. Cialis, which last longer, does not have a generic twin yet and is really expensive. I have a friend, though, who gets it for $3 per 100 mg pill with his insurance and he gives me some. I like to combine small does (ex: a third of Cialis with two 20 mg sildenafil) to expand the window of opportunity.

Posts.Title: Erectile Function - should I get my hopes up?

Posts.Content: Dooley Definitely give ED meds a try before surgey. I was having occasional ED for a couple of years but when I started taking Cialis it was like I was 18 again. Going into the surgery I said to my doc try to spare the nerves. He said "I will but getting all the cancer is my priority and your continence is second. Your wife will love you even if you have ED." My PSA checks since then have both been undetectable. Dr. Kibel saved a good urethra stem and my incontinence problems have been almost non existent. He saved half the nerves. Since then I was able to get semi erections, big as ever but not real firm. On my PA advice, I switched from Cialis to generic Viagra (sildenafil) last week and the early results are promising.

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing DaVinci if already Impotent pre-op?

Posts.Content: My now-retired urologist also was not a big fan of the PSA test, saying it caused more anxiety than anything else and that a DRE by a skilled urologist was a more accurate predictor of Prostate cancer. I was happy to hear that since my brother, who had prostate cancer in 2011, said the biopsy was the most painful thing he had ever been through. For two years my primary care guy kept telling me I needed a biopsy (my PSA went up and down, mostly in the 3s) and that my urologist was an out-of-touch dinosaur. Every time I went to my urologist, though, he'd say you don't need a biopsy. And I'd say great. He finally retired and when my PSA went up to 4 in May the new guy said I needed a biopsy. Well, the lowdown is the biopsy was not bad at all, not really even a pain in the ass, and it was positive in five cores, including a 4+3. I had the surgery in August and they downgraded that core to 3+4. I still worry--even though my surgeon thinks he got it all I did have a positive focal point--and I wonder how much the two years I didn't have the biopsy mattered. Hopefully, it won't at all.

Posts.Title: I wish they never invented the PSA test

Posts.Content: The PSA number is all that matters. It took a year for ol' Memo to come all the way back. Lots of pee-squirting, water balloon-like floppy erections before that but a gradual improvement. Now, with the aid of sildenafil (generic Viagra) it is all the way back to strong like bull. Be patient, buddy.

Posts.Title: I wish they never invented the PSA test

Posts.Content: Hi Jimmy, Good advice from everyone so far. The only thing I'd add is to definitely get second opinions from radiologists and surgeons. After I was diagnosed by a UMass urologist, I saw an oncologist, a radiologist and another urologist/surgeon. The radiologist told me he could do radiation but since I had it before (for testicular cancer when I was 37) it might not be the most effective and that because I had a small prostate he wouldn't do seeds because they would negatively affect my urethra. He recommended surgery. My first doctor only did open surgery and insisted I would heal just as fast as robotic, but I had read that was not true. I did some research and got my second surgical opinion from Dr. Adam Kibel, the head of urology at Boston's world renown Dana Farber Clinic. Kibel has done thousands of Da Vinci surgeries and I went with him. Despite a rare post surgery complication, I am now five months post op and 100 percent back to normal, other than a little ED which Viagra is helping. All of those second opinions (and associated bone scans and MRIs and other pre-op tests) cost me under $800 in co pays. Get as much info as you can, but act quickly with your PSA rising like it is. Good luck.

Posts.Title: First Post-op PSA Results

Posts.Content: To all my brothers and their wives, Merry Christmas and Happy New Year. 2015 was not a great year for us. I was diagnosed with PC in May. Had the Da Vinci operation in August and a rare complication put me back in the hospital in September. Then in October I got facial cellulitis (may or may not have been related to PC operation according to the doctors) and my daughter in law was diagnosed with uterine cancer and had a hysterectomy at 34 years old. On December 2 our beloved 12 and a half year old dog Yaz died and yesterday my wife cracked up her car. But you know what? We're all still here. The kids and grand kids are healthy. My wife didn't get hurt. My daughter in law is doing fine. My four month PSA came back at <0.02 and other than a little ED to remind me I would not even know I had the surgery or complications. My Patriots are heading to the Super Bowl again and my Bruins are one point out of first place. I spent all this week playing guitar and singing with my students, and today I am playing Christmas Eve golf with my buddies because it is supposed to hit 65 here in New England. Life is as good as you make it --so make yours a good one. Merry Christmas.

Posts.Title: Fifteen hours to go....

Posts.Content: Today marks one year since I had my prostate removed via Da Vinci surgery at Boston's Brigham & Women's Hospital by Dana Farber head urologist Dr. Adam Kibel. This morning I'm sitting in a cottage on the shores of Little Squam Lake in New Hampshire with my wife, my daughter, her fiance and my hound dog Yeats. Yesterday, I went tubing, today I'll go waterskiiing. Two days ago I missed a three foot putt to lose my golf league playoff. In two weeks I'll return to my job teaching high school English. Life is good. One year later, other than a little ED issue that is solved by generic Viagra, it is like the PC and surgery never happened.

Posts.Title: One year out and it was like it never happened

Posts.Content: Hi Rob and Rich That constipation can be a real serious problem. Two or three weeks post surgery in 2011 my brother's bowels stopped working totally.There's a name for it but I can't recalled what it is--something like illyis. He was in incredible pain and his neighbor rushed him to the hospital. He was readmitted for eight days and fed intravenously. The only thing he was allowed to eat was ice chips. He was bored out of his mind. They had him walking up and down the aisles. Finally after eight days he farted and they sent him home. Knowing that, when I had the surgery last year I ate the stool softener and laxatives like candy. Good luck.

He was in incredible pain and his neighbor rushed him to the hospital. He was readmitted for eight days and fed intravenously. The only thing he was allowed to eat was ice chips. He was bored out of his mind. They had him walking up and down the aisles. Finally after eight days he farted and they sent him home. Knowing that, when I had the surgery last year I ate the stool softener and laxatives like candy. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Glad tidings to all

Posts.Content: Today marks one year since I had my prostate removed via Da Vinci surgery at Boston's Brigham & Women's Hospital by Dana Farber head urologist Dr. Adam Kibel. This morning I'm sitting in a cottage on the shores of Little Squam Lake in New Hampshire with my wife, my daughter, her fiance and my hound dog Yeats. Yesterday, I went tubing, today I'll go waterskiiing. Two days ago I missed a three foot putt to lose my golf league playoff. In two weeks I'll return to my job teaching high school English. Life is good. One year later, other than a little ED issue that is solved by generic Viagra, it is like the PC and surgery never happened.

Posts.Title: Still In The Zero Club

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Coyote thanks for the info about "phantom" squirts. I'm 13 days post-op and had some dribbles the first few days. The last 3 days a couple times a day it felt like it but nothing. I thought I was nuts.) Yup, Coyote, I remember being baffled by the phantom squirts but it is really common. A lot of guys on this forum have written about it. I wore pads for a few weeks just in case but hated them. My privates got really chaffed no matter which ones I tried. Once I realized they were ghosts squirts I just took a chance (I'm a high school teacher) and went without. I remember running to the men's room at school a couple times during my first weeks back to check my shorts but they were always bone dry. And my wife pointed out that even if a drop came out into my jockey shorts no one would notice. She said it happens to women, especially pregnant women, all the time. One thing that did discourage me for a while is that when I had a (somewhat limp dick) orgasm, pee would come out. At first it was a lot but a few months ago that stopped entirely too. And good timing with generic Viagra and a hair elastic have solved the limp problem.

Posts.Title: YAHOO !!!! PSA .01 90 days after radiation.

Posts.Content: Rooster, one thing I and many others have found is that, post op, when you have to go, you really have to go. Without that second brake Chuck mentioned, the feeling of urgency can be acute and you need to take care of it ASAP. I peed the bed once in the first month. I had a hard time with the pads chaffing my junk so I didn't use them at all after three weeks but I did answer every call to pee urgently. The only time I peed the bed again was when I took an Adavan to help me sleep three months post op and slept through my bladder's wake up call. That being said, I believe the majority of guys return to full continence. In my case it was relatively quickly, other than pee coming out during orgasm. That took a half year or so to stop. My surgeon said he was able to spare a good urethra stem and predicted incontinence would resolve quickly and it did. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Incontitent discussion w/MD

Posts.Content: Hello all, The good news is I went to Brigham & Women's Hospital in Boston for my four month post op and my PSA is still <0.02 undetectable. Yeeha. Despite all the complications I had post surgery I have to say I feel great now and almost like it never happened...except for Mr. Softee. I talked to my Physician Assistant about ED--which is always awkward since she's about 30 years old and good looking to boot. I told her my dick grows but does not get real firm, kind of like a water balloon, and when I have an orgasm a little pee comes out. She said the pee thing could be here to stay, at least short term. She said the erections should get firmer over the next year. I have been using Cialis I get from a friend because my insurer won't cover the 5 mg daily prescription. My PA said some guys have found Viagra works better and gave me a prescription for 100 mg pills. If I took that much Viagra or Cialis pre-surgery I would have broke some bedroom windows and knocked everything off the nightstand. That was then, this is now. She also said some guys get their prescriptions for Viagra filled by online Canadian pharmacies. My questions are 1. Has anyone found that Viagra indeed works better and 2. Has anyone used online Canadian pharmacies to fill their Viagra prescription with satisfactory results.

Posts.Content: Hello all, The good news is I went to Brigham & Women's Hospital in Boston for my four month post op and my PSA is still <0.02 undetectable. Yeeha. Despite all the complications I had post surgery I have to say I feel great now and almost like it never happened...except for Mr. Softee. I talked to my Physician Assistant about ED--which is always awkward since she's about 30 years old and good looking to boot. I told her my dick grows but does not get real firm, kind of like a water balloon, and when I have an orgasm a little pee comes out. She said the pee thing could be here to stay, at least short term. She said the erections should get firmer over the next year. I have been using Cialis I get from a friend because my insurer won't cover the 5 mg daily prescription. My PA said some guys have found Viagra works better and gave me a prescription for 100 mg pills. If I took that much Viagra or Cialis pre-surgery I would have broke some bedroom windows and knocked everything off the nightstand. That was then, this is now. She also said some guys get their prescriptions for Viagra filled by online Canadian pharmacies. My questions are 1. Has anyone found that Viagra indeed works better and 2. Has anyone used online Canadian pharmacies to fill their Viagra prescription with satisfactory results.
Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Older brother had DaVinci in 2011 PSA 4.1 at diagnosis (had been up and down in 3s for years) Biopsy at UMass Worcester May 2015. Five of 13 cores positive, three 3+3, one 3+4. one 4+3 No perineural invasion. Da Vinci surgery at Brigham & Women's Boston on Aug. 6, 2015 Nerves taken on left, spared on right Catheter out in 7 days Pathology show tumors on both sides, all reclassified 3+4 Stage T2C NO Focally present tumor on right posterior zone (doc thinks it is nothing) Lymphocele infection on August 29 required five day re-hospitalization and drain insertion. Drain in until Sept. 18 Virtually no incontinence Some ED, switch to sildenafil produced great results. Follow up PSA test on Sept. 9, Dec. 10 and March 5 all <0.02. Posts.Title: Mr. Softee still in Zero Club

Posts.Content: Wow, Mike. That sucks. You are probably like me. I actually don't care what happens to me--I've had a full and great life-- but please, God, spare my family. A month after my Da Vinci, my daughter in law was diagnosed with uterine cancer. She is 34 and the mother of my grand kids who are just 3 and 6. She had a hysterectomy in October and so far all is good. She has an appointment tomorrow at Dana Farber in Boston to set up her radiation treatments. Even though her cancer is the same type as my prostate cancer, there is no PSA like test for women so they are doing radiation as a preventative measure. God has been good to me so far--my daughter was diagnosed with leukemia in 1988 when she was 20 months old and is now a beautiful and healthy 29. I had testicular cancer in 1989 and, other than losing ol' lefty, no problem since. I pray you and your son have the same good fortune.

Posts.Title: Mr. Softee still in Zero Club

Posts.Content: Hello all. I haven't been on this forum for awhile. My brother Ed and I have both had surgery to remove our prostates. His was in early 2011. Mine in 2016. His PSA never went to the zero club, although it was close. It stayed at .03 for years but last year started to creep up. It hit 0.7 two weeks ago. The doctor said the Big C was back somewhere. They did an MRI hoping it would be a small spot near the prostate area that they could zap but didn't see one. A bone scan didn't reveal anything. Now the docs say he needs salvage radiation. We both thought we were done with this. We even won a golf tournament together two years ago, and we both had knee replacements last year. After seven years this is a shock. Can anyone who has had salvage radiation give him any advice? How tired did you get? Any other side effects? Did it work? Thanks.

Posts.Title: Brother going for salvage radiation--what should he expect

Posts.Content: Delta, you and I have the same stats. I am now 15 months post op and I don't worry any more. I think if it was going to come back it would have by now. I had the same 1mm positive margin as you and my doctor told me post op that he was "100 percent certain" it was nothing. He said when the robot pulls out the prostate it can squeeze some cancer cells to the edge and that is why it shows a positive reading, albeit a tiny one. The good news is I was totally continent almost immediately and the great news is my ED, with the aid of generic Viagra, is gone like a David Ortiz home run ball. The bad news is I am going back in the hospital for a total knee replacement Monday. But, as Meat Loaf sang, "two out of three ain't bad."

Posts.Title: One year from surgery

Posts.Content: Hey Oshguy, Feels good to have those tubes out, eh? As far as the positive margins, my surgeon said he is almost positive that my positive focal point is nothing to worry about, just a bit of cancer that got squeezed to the edge when the robot pulled the prostate out. I hope he is right. Maybe that is what yours are too. My guy also had me do a PSA at one month, although many wait for three. It came back <0.02 so I was really buoyed by that. Even though I didn't get a great erection and still don't (more like Mr, Softee), I actually had an orgasm at three weeks. My wife is very sexy and patient and we made it work. The orgasm felt like an air rifle, if that makes sense, and I think a little pee may have come out first although Karen said she didn't feel it. Later that day the infected lymphocele dropped me to my knees and put me back in the hospital. Doctors said the two are not related but I am kind of scared to jump back into the sack. Guess I'll have to man up.

Posts.Title: Pathology report received, not what I wanted

Posts.Content: Hello Wilde et al, Life is indeed good here in Central Massachusetts too. My orchard is producing great apples and pears, my organic garden is filled with tomatoes and peppers and beans, my wife is beautiful and loves me and my kids and grandkids are all happy and healthy. I'm looking forward to teaching AP English this school year to my great students and getting back on the golf course. Just had DaVinci eight days ago, had the the catheter out yesterday and am nearly 100 percent continent already. Visited spectacular Yellowstone National Park two weeks before the surgery and body-surfed in the Atlantic right before I went in. Beat testicular cancer in 1989 (luckily you only need one) and had a colloid cyst removed from my brain in 2002. The sun is shining and I'm on the right side of the grass. I've got no complaints. I toast you all with a shot of Jameson's and a Samuel Adams' Boston Ale.

My knees were both solid white on the scan and every other broken bone and sprain from long ago sports injuries showed up too. As they say, getting old does suck, but it beats the alternative.

Posts.Content: I get generic Viagra (sidenafil) really cheaply from LUEA Pharmacy in Michigan. You need a prescription but without insurance it was only $63 for ninety 20mg-pills. I take five at once and it is working better every time. A couple of caveats--you need to take Viagra/sidenafil on an empty stomach, the effects start in an hour or so, and they only last for a few hours. Posts.Title: YIPPIE and YAHOO!!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider is that a safe amount to take? such a high dose probably increases the chances of side effects, and spending an evening in the er for priapism does sound like a great time Hi Southsider, As Ron pointed out, the normal prescribed dose is 100 mg, so five 20s are OK. My prescription says "take 50 to 100 mg once or twice a week as needed." I have found the biggest factor in how it works is to not eat before I take it. If your stomach is full, the food absorbs the sildenafil and it doesn't work as well. I have taken it and waited a while and then ate before sex and it still worked. Drinking alcohol definitely limits the effectiveness too, as does being overly tired.

Posts.Title: Good news on ED meds

Posts.Content: Hello brothers, I have great news on the ED med front. There are bunch of places that you can get sildenafil for short money. I found it works great, better than Cialis. The key is to take it on an empty or near-empty stomach. I also found it works best if I don't drink more than a beer or two. I take four or five tabs at a time although 2 or 3 would probably do. Just don't want to let my beautiful wife down. The good news is that you can get deep discounts from Blinkhealth.com and GoodRX.com and probably a host of other online coupons. CVS wanted $460+ for 90 sildenafil 20 mg. tabs but accepted a Blinkheath.com coupon that only cost me $54. A friend of mine who also had PC got 30 tabs for $20 from Price Chopper, a supermarket chain here in Central Mass. You still need a prescription and you can't couple it with insurance but at this price it is cheaper anyway. My insurer wouldn't cover ED meds at all anyway.

Posts.Title: Staying in the Zero Club

Posts.Content: I am two years out of surgery now. Incontinence was never a big problem, just some mostly phantom squirts for the first six months or so. When I had an orgasm for the first year or so pee came out. That is normal and will go away. The ED for me took a little longer. Erections were more like water balloons for the first year. Now,with the aid of sildenafil (generic Viagra)I am back to oak. You can get coupons to buy sildenafil with a prescription just about anywhere and you can get it way cheaper than through insurance. I just bought 90 tabs for $54 through Blinkhealth.com and a friend of mine got 30 tabs for under $20 with a coupon from GoodhealthRX.com. I take five 20 mg tabs at a time. You'll get there. You (and your wife and/or girlfriend) just have to be patient as the nerves regenerate.

Posts.Title: Just a short 4 month update

Posts.Content: Hello guys and dolls, My wife and I discovered a trick that works great for ED. I had the robotic surgery in August. I didn't have any real problems with incontinence but my progress with ED was not as fast as I hoped. I had a dry orgasm after just a few weeks but my erections were more like floppy water balloons than like oak limbs. They got a little better when I switched from Cialis to Sildenafil (generic Viagra) and still a little better when I mixed the two (low dose of both) but the erections were still not great. I was starting to think about going with the needle but the thought of anything sharp sticking into Memo the Trouser Monster scared the hell out of me. Not to be too graphic, but last week my wife put one of her little hair elastics around Memo's base and then we started fooling around and. voila--oak, or at least rock maple, and it stayed hard a long time, pleasing both of us. It worked again a couple of days ago. I don't know if it's the elastic or that I am taking longer and knowing she is satisfied too, but my orgasms were great. BTW, these elastics are tiny so don't forget to take them off when you're done.

Posts.Title: just found out

Posts.Content: Hi Tghag I dreaded a biopsy because my brother told me it was the worst pain he had ever experienced. When I finally had one I didn't think it was bad at all. Surgery is the same--I had a rare complication but even then, in just four and a half months, I feel totally back to normal other than dealing with some ED. I actually felt pretty much back to normal after two months despite the complication. As far as a second opinion goes, you should definitely get one. In my case, it was totally covered by my insurance. The urologist who diagnosed me at UMass wanted to do the surgery but he only did open surgery. He claimed open has the same healing time as robotic. But I had read that is not true so I got a second opinion from Dr. Adam Kibel, the head of urology at Harvard University and Dana Farber/Brigham & Women's in Boston. My wife and I decided to go with Dr. Kibel. Was it the right choice? I don't know. Maybe the complication would not have occurred if I had the surgery at UMass but even then I was still back teaching within two months and haven't missed a day since. My point is the second opinion gives you options. Do some research and find a top doctor who has performed the surgery many times and get your second opinion from him or her. They all have giant egos and love to operate. The only way to know the true pathology is to have the prostate removed and dissected. Good luck. You'll be fine

Posts.Title: Six-Year Anniversary

Posts.Content: I am one month post op and totally continent. I have hardly ever done Kegels. I still have the drain in my abdomen from an infected lymphocele that put me in the hospital last week but that is draining fluid, not urine. I don't even use a pad when I go out. Sometimes when I sneeze or laugh I feel a tiny squirt but then find nothing has actually come out when I check my shorts. I've always had a bizarre problem peeing in front of other people since i was a kid--nothing is worse than having a few beers in you at Gilllette Stadium and then getting to the front of a long line at the urinal and not being able to go--and I'm wondering if I unconsciously developed those muscles to hold it over the years. I have found since surgery that to start my pee now I can simply do a kegel and release it and the flow starts.

Posts.Title: Value of Second Opinions and Newly Diagnosed Questions

Posts.Content: I hope that anyone who is facing surgery and perusing this great and caring website sees this. It is not just about having an orgasm in such a short time--that was an unexpected bonus--but also I feel better and better every day. I still dribble a little pee, mostly if I have a beer or two, but my shorts and/or a pad are hardly wet when I take them off before i go to bed. Other than one spillage early on, I have been totally dry at night. I'm going back to teaching high school next Monday, just three and a half weeks after surgery. I know I'll get tired--hell, sophomores could tire out the Energizer Bunny--but I am confident I'll be fine. I mowed two acres yesterday and hit some balls in my yard today. I realized when I took a full swing with a wedge that I should give golf a little more time. It almost seems like having the catheter or peeing pink urine was years ago, and not just a couple of weeks. Other problems-- such as the giant bruises that appeared two days post-op, sleep interruption every 15 minutes for false urination urgency, or a rash on my genitals--have been overcome, often with encouragement or advice from the brothers on this forum. I'm sure they'll be more challenges and I am naturally worried about my first post-op PSA on Sept. 9. But for others just starting this journey I can say definitively that it hasn't been nearly as bad as I feared. I know some have bad experiences--my brother's inability to move his bowels kept him in the hospital for an extra 8 days when he had the surgery four years ago--but most people end up fine. (Even after that, my brother was back at work and on the golf course within two months). Find a good surgeon and with the loving support of your spouse, you'll do fine. I had a cancerous testicle removed in 1989 and a benign brain tumor removed in 2002. As one of my daughters said when I told them in May that I had been diagnosed with PC, "Well, that's a good cancer, right?" Odd way to put it, but I know what she meant.

Posts.Title: Sex after DaVinci--Houston, we have liftoff!

Posts.Content: I too had a PSA that fluctuated mostly in the 3.0-3.9 range for four years and one time even got to 5.7. My primary care doc kept telling me to get a biopsy since my older brother had prostate cancer in 2010-11. Every time I went to my elderly urologist though he would do a DRE and say I didn't need one, reasoning that if I had cancer my PSA would not go up and down, only up. That was fine with me because my brother said the biopsy was the most painful thing he had ever had in his life. That urologist retired last year. My first PSA with his replacement was 3 something so we agreed to wait on a biopsy but when it went to 4.1 in the spring we decided on a biopsy. It wasn't that bad. It was quick--like getting a dozen bee stings in a minute or two and almost no soreness immediately afterward. Biopsy came back positive in five of 13 cores. I had the DaVinci robotic surgery on Aug. 6. My pathology report shows a minuscule positive focal margin which my surgeon Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Brigham & Women's/Dana Farber, said is probably nothing. I hope so. My former urologist is windsurfing in Aruba and I'm sitting here wishing that I had listened to my PCP and went to a different urologist years earlier. My advice Bill is to get a another biopsy. It's not that bad and you don't want to wait like I did and at best be saddled with worry for years to come.

Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: I just had my first orgasm post surgery. Didn't really achieve a great erection but enough to accomplish penetration with my beautiful and understanding wife. The orgasm felt great even though it was shorter than my pre-surgery ones and nothing came out. I am psyched. The only real problem during my three weeks of recovery, beyond the usual swelling, aches and pains and the damn catheter for one week, was false urination urgency that woke me up constantly and that seems to be solved the last two nights by taking a couple of Ibuprofen before I hit the hay. I also have a little dribbling later in the day, especially if I have a beer or glass of wine, and one night last week I wet the bed like my 3-year-old grandson. (Thank God for mattress protectors.) I can't sleep with a diaper or pad on because my scrotum gets incredibly itchy. I try to wear the pads during the day as seldom as possible for that reason so I just have wash my jockey shorts a lot. I'll have to wear the pads next week when I go back to teaching high school. But back to sex. I feel incredibly blessed by my beautiful and understanding wife. I thought it would take at least three months before I had a big O, not three weeks. I can live with Mr. Softee as long as I can achieve full continence. I have to say the skill of my surgeon, Dr. Adam Kibel, is a huge factor in this rapid recovery. For anyone who is contemplating surgery, make sure you seek out an experienced and highly rated surgeon. Don't worry about hurting someone's feelings--it is your life--and your insurance will cover a great surgeon the same as it covers a beginner. I was a journalist most of my life and used to asking a lot of tough questions. When my urologist at UMASS said he wanted to do traditional surgery because he had never learned to do robotic, my reporter's BS detector went off. I did some research and discovered robotic generally has a shorter recovery period. I looked up Dr. Kibel, head of urology at Brigham and Women's/Dana Farber, and made an appointment for a second opinion consult. I decided to have Dr. Kibel do the surgery in Boston. I'm glad I did--and so is my wife!

Posts.Title: Sex after DaVinci--Houston, we have liftoff!

Posts.Content: I am one month post op and totally continent. I have hardly ever done Kegels. I still have the drain in my abdomen from an infected lymphocele that put me in the hospital last week but that is draining fluid, not urine. I don't even use a pad when I go out. Sometimes when I sneeze or laugh I feel a tiny squirt but then find nothing has actually come out when I check my shorts. I've always had a bizarre problem peeing in front of other people since i was a kid--nothing is worse than having a few beers in you at Gilllette Stadium and then getting to the front of a long line at the urinal and not being able to go--and I'm wondering if I unconsciously developed those muscles to hold it over the years. I have found since surgery that to start my pee now I can simply do a kegel and release it and the flow starts.

Posts.Title: Kegels for how long?

Posts.Content: My incontinence seemed to get way worse yesterday. After I had the catheter removed I had almost none although I would feel the urge to go at night. Yesterday I had quite a few daytime squirts and last night I was up every half hour feeling like I had to pee (even though hardly any would come out).. I thought I'd go crazy. Finally, at 3 a.m., i took an Ibuprofen and, voila, I slept like baby till 7:30 a.m. I am hoping that is the key. Today, I've had no leakage whatsoever. For years before the surgery I had occasional urgency problems, but only at night. I would take Flomax to solve them but I would still need to get up at least once a night to urinate. My urologist said at the time that once was normal.

Posts.Title: Kegels for how long?

Posts.Content: One factor that I'm sure your doctors will talk about is that the radiation is a good back up if cancer remains after surgery. I believe the surgical option is generally off the table if radiation doesn't get it all I had a tiny positive margin, a "focally present tumor" after my surgery in August. My surgeon said then he was sure it was nothing and a result of cancer being squeezed to the edge when the robot pulled out the prostate. I'm not sure if they could have seen that before the surgery ended. So far it looks like he was right as I have had three PSA tests come back at undetectable. Good luck with your decision. You'll be fine either way.

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and weighing my options

Posts.Content: As Chuck mentioned, make sure you don't have sex a day or two before the retest. I know my PSA jumped a couple of points when I did. I finally had a biopsy that revealed I did have PC but the up and down nature of my tests (3s went up to 5s when I had sex the night before and then back down to 3s when I didn't) and negative DREs had me delay the biopsy for years. My brother had told me the biopsy was incredibly painful but in actuality mine wasn't that bad at all.

Posts.Title: What a week --but still in zero club

Posts.Content: They say not to mix them also but I had great results when I switched from Cialis to Viagra and they overlapped (I took a 20 mg of Cialis one day, didn't have sex, and the next day I took 100 of Viagra. The Cialis lasts for three days so they were both in play and the results were great.) I've been using Viagra now with pretty good results but I took a Cialis 20 mig recently and that worked well too. The crucial thing I discovered with Viagra is it works best on an empty stomach and no more than one beer or one drink.

Posts.Content: One factor that I'm sure your doctors will talk about is that the radiation is a good back up if cancer remains after surgery. I believe the surgical option is generally off the table if radiation doesn't get it all I had a tiny positive margin, a "focally present tumor" after my surgery in August. My surgeon said then he was sure it was nothing and a result of cancer being squeezed to the edge when the robot pulled out the prostate. I'm not sure if they could have seen that before the surgery ended. So far it looks like he was right as I have had three PSA tests come back at undetectable. Good luck with your decision. You'll be fine either way.

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and weighing my options

Posts.Content: Getting old is a trip. This week I had four doctors appointments at three different hospitals. I had so much medical stuff going on (doc looked at cyst on my vocal chords, then I had an ultrasound of my kidneys because my creatine level was too high at my last checkup, then I had my two-year endoscopy to look at my Barrett's Esophagus, and finally today I went to my GP to review the blood work and ultrasound.). While I was at UMASS with the cyst doc, my blood pressure was 175/95. At first the nurses said we can't let you leave till it goes down. I told them I have "white coat syndrome" and that with their mandate there was no way it would go down. Ninety minutes and several checks later it was 210/102. They finally let me go and when I checked it at home (post one Sam Adams lager) it was 140/77. So far, so good on all the appointments. Cyst is coming out at some point and may change my voice--some would say after listening to my band that any change would be good.--but doc is virtually certain it is not cancer. Ultrasound and blood work showed creatine rise was probably due to walking 18 holes in 90 degree heat a day before initial test without drinking enough water. Now it is back to normal. Endoscopy found more damage to my esophagus since 2015, but it is probably more Barrett's and not cancer. Awaiting biopsy result. Best thing was during my visit with GP to review all this today he mentioned that my PSA was still 0.01 undetectable. I had forgot that I asked him to check off the PSA box on the blood work sheet. I did that because I have a checkup at Brigham and Women's in September and I figured I may as well get the number now. This made me think, though, how distant that PC operation seems now. It was only two years ago I had my prostate out (and I had a knee replaced in the meantime). For anyone just embarking on this journey I hope you will be able to just forget about it in a couple of years like I have. Most of you will. Good luck all.

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and weighing my options

Posts.Content: Hi wifeinworry, My PSA went up and down for years before I was biopsied and diagnosed. It went from 2 something to 3 something to 5 something--and then it went down to 3 something again. My urologist kept saying it wouldn't go down if it was PC and he never felt anything on a DRE. He retired and my new guy ordered a biopsy when it went from 3 to 4 something and he felt a lump. Did I have PC the whole time? I don't know. The lump he felt was not cancerous, according to the biopsy, but other cores were. Depending on your husband's age, 3.1 PSA may be in the normal range.

Posts.Content: Trinity I had the exact same thing happen. My urologist at UMAss did not do robotic surgery and that is what I decided I wanted after research. I got my second opinion at Brigham and Women's/Dana Farber and decided to have DaVinci there. I called the doc at UMass and he wasn't there so I left him a message explaining my decision. He then left me a message basically telling me to go to hell and that he did not want me as a patient anymore. I was shocked. They all have giant egos.

Posts.Title: Urge to pee waking me up

Posts.Content: Hey man, I am a week short of one year post op and other than a little ED (nothing that pills don't cure), I feel no different than I did pre-surgery. Actually, I feel better. I broke 80 for the first time, and second and third time, on the links this summer. My recovery was swift, even with a rare surgical complication. I still play with my band, still love my job teaching high school English, and still go to breakfast with my kids and grand kids whenever we can. Three months post op I cut down a 100-foot ash tree and harvested four cords of firewood. In three weeks my brother (prostate cancer and DaVinci in 2011) will play in a member guest. He is 100 percent recovered too. I hope and wish and know your recovery will be even swifter since you are 17 years younger than me. Good luck.

Posts.Title: One year anniversary.

Posts.Content: I am going to Boston to get a CT scan of my lymphocele. Hopefully it is collapsed and they can take the drain I have in my stomach out. This has been a long slog--since my DaVinci surgery on Aug. 6 I have had a catheter and/or drain in for 26 days. I know others on this forum have had a lot worse time and more problems--in the midst of all this I did get great news that my PSA is now <0.02--but I feel like a prisoner in leg irons, except my chains are a plastic tube with a bag at the end. Hopefully in four hours the bag, the tube, and the drain will be just a memory and I can go back to teaching, playing golf and the yard work that has been neglected for two months.

Posts.Title: Urge to pee waking me up

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone. I may try foregoing my usual two beers in the evening but that will be tough. I love me some Sam Adams Boston Ale. Wishbonedays, I am glad you wrote about feeling like you were going out of your mind. The only night post-op I've slept more than 90 minutes in a row was when I took an Oxycodone and an Adavan, but then I woke up feeling like I'd been drugged. As far as Red Sox go, I gave up on them early this year. No pitching. Here in New England we are all going out of our minds for the Patriots to defend their title. Even if Brady is guilty of telling the clubhouse guys to let a little air out of the balls, Deflategate is a sham and had nothing to do with the Pats winning. In fact, they scored 35 points in the second half of the Colts game after the ball was switched. NFL is totally out to get the Pats.

Posts.Content: I switched from Cialis to Sildenafil (generic Viagra) after a year with great results. You can get a prescription for Sildenafil from your doc and then you have to find a family pharmacy that will fill it cheaply. The hospital pharmacies and chains like CVS will charge you an arm and a leg but independent pharmacies will sell it way cheaper. I pay $60 for 90 pills (20 mg each)and that is without using insurance. I started off taking five at a time, now I just take a 2 or 3 and it's like I'm 18 again. I live in Massachusetts. At first I was filling it through an online pharmacy in Michigan but now I fill it through a pharmacy 15 miles from my house.
