Posts.Title: Wish me luck today

Posts.Content: Hello brothers, Things are going well for me 12 days post op. I feel like I could play golf but know I shouldn't. I'm wearing a pad during the day and have tiny squirts when I stand up suddenly or cough.(I'm not sure anything even comes out but it feels like it does.) I'm dry at night but wake up a dozen times feeling like I need to urinate. When I get up hardly anything comes out. Not great sleeping weather here in Central Mass anyway with high humidity. I'm wicked tired every day because of waking so often but other than that I feel great. Has anyone else had this waking problem? I know it is relatively minor compared to so many others that I see on this forum but I teach high school English and in two weeks we go back and i hope I am not dragging my arse into class every day. Maybe i should stop drinking coffee in the morning and beer at night but that would be awfully hard. Still nervous about the .01 focally present tumor on my pathology report but my surgeon, Dr. Adam Kibel, said he is confident it is nothing. My first post-op PSA/follow-up visit is on Sept. 6 so i guess I will find out if Dr. Kibel is right. BTW, I can't say enough good things about Dr. Kibel and his staff at Brigham and Women's/Dana Farber in Boston. Class acts!

Posts.Title: Wish me luck today

Posts.Content: Hey man, I am a week short of one year post op and other than a little ED (nothing that pills don't cure), I feel no different than I did pre-surgery. Actually, I feel better. I broke 80 for the first time, and second and third time, on the links this summer. My recovery was swift, even with a rare surgical complication. I still play with my band, still love my job teaching high school English, and still go to breakfast with my kids and grand kids whenever we can. Three months post op I cut down a 100-foot ash tree and harvested four cords of firewood. In three weeks my brother (prostate cancer and DaVinci in 2011) will play in a member guest. He is 100 percent recovered too. I hope and wish and know your recovery will be even swifter since you are 17 years younger than me. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Might as well jump right in

Posts.Content: I am going to Boston to get a CT scan of my lymphocele. Hopefully it is collapsed and they can take the drain I have in my stomach out. This has been a long slog--since my DaVinci surgery on Aug. 6 I have had a catheter and/or drain in for 26 days. I know others on this forum have had a lot worse time and more problems--in the midst of all this I did get great news that my PSA is now <0.02--but I feel like a prisoner in leg irons, except my chains are a plastic tube with a bag at the end. Hopefully in four hours the bag, the tube, and the drain will be just a memory and I can go back to teaching, playing golf and the yard work that has been neglected for two months.

Posts.Content: Congrats Michigan and welcome back. I owe you big time for connecting me with LUEA Pharmacy in Michigan last year. I got generic Vigra (sildenafil, ninety 20 ml pills for $60) from them till last month but then Massachusetts told them they couldn't ship here anymore. The pharmacist at LUEA suggested I try to find a family pharmacy in Mass that would do the same deal and I did-- just 15 miles from my house. Back in the saddle and it's thanks to you. I thank you, My wife thanks you.

Posts.Title: Some good news

Posts.Content: It is normal. This was major surgery and it beats the hell out of you. You were upside down for a lot of it--it scared the hell out of me when my balls turned purple a couple of weeks post op--plus the anesthesia stays in your body for a long time. To paraphrase the Rolling Stones, time is on your side. You think you feel great but then in a week you feel better and that is how it goes every week for at least a few months.

Posts.Title: Path Report, and nagging question

Posts.Content: Hi PCWife 3 I had the same thing. I'd pee and it would be a strong stream and then it felt like the brakes were painfully jammed on. It didn't bother me much but after three weeks I developed a urinary tract infection and infected lymphocele. I don't think the UTI was related to that. I'm sure the lymphocele wasn't. It was caused by leaking lymph node fluid but I know the docs investigated urine leaking from my bladder before they pronounced there was no connection. I think Jim's advice about moving the appointment up is solid.

Posts.Title: Health

Posts.Content: Good for you, Oshguy. My brother ended up back in the hospital for eight days two weeks after his surgery in 2011. They fed him by IV and all he could do was chew ice chips and walk. They let him go home once he farted. The condition is called something like illyis and it is when your bowels basically forget how to work. Scared by that when I had my surgery on Aug. 6, I had no problem pooping because i immediately walked and ate the stool softener and laxatives like they were candy. On the drain front, I didn't go home with one but three weeks later I developed an infected and incredibly painful lymphocele and ended up back in the hospital for five days. I've had a drain now for the past 15 days. It was putting out 1200 cc a day for awhile. Yesterday it was still at 100. Today it was 6 cc. If I have another day below 10 cc they will give me a CT scan to make sure the lymphocele is collapsed and then take the drain out.I have my fingers crossed.

Posts.Title: Long history of prostate problems - wondering about symptoms, etc.

Posts.Content: Hi Pierre I had the same experience with a twist. (I also live in Central MA btw). For years my PSA fluctuated between low 3s and one time even got to 5 something. Since my brother had prostate cancer in 2011, my primary care doc kept urging me to get a biopsy. When I went to my urologist, an older doctor who had operated on me for testicular cancer in 1989, he would do a DRE and tell me I didn't need a biopsy. That was fine with me. He said my normal PSA was probably 3 something and that it would not go up--and down--if it was cancer. He retired last year. The new urologist on first examination said my 3 PSA was OK but iif it went up he'd want a biopsy. It went up to 4.1 in February--my wife and I had made love the night before and CPO2 is right--sex does make it go up. I wasn't too worried but I had the biopsy in May--it was positive with three 6s and two 7s (one a 4+3) Gleason. I had robotic surgery at Brigham and Women's last Thursday. Hardly any pain but catheter is a hassle. I got my pathology results yesterday and Dr. Adam Kibel said there is one positive focal margin but he thinks it may be nothing. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New Guy / Family History

Posts.Content: Hello guys, I was supposed to have a "virtual visit" with my surgeon at Brigham & Women's today. The technology worked on my end--kind of like Skype--but not on his. He called me instead and said he had never received the PSA report from blood I had drawn at a local hospital. (I'm about an hour drive from Boston). I was disappointed because I wanted to hear "undetectable," a word that is magic to my ears. He said the local hospital has to give me the result if I ask, even though when I asked for it previously they said they didn't. I drove to the local hospital, told them what he said, and they gave it to me. The report says 0.01. Every time I had my blood drawn post op at Brigham & Women's it was <0.02. My surgeon is gone for the long weekend and I can't ask him, but it seems to me that I had read on this forum that they are the same, just a different reporting method. Am I correct? Am I still in the zero club?

Posts.Title: Bone Scan ???

Posts.Content: I am at 11 months post-op and only recently did I achieve completely dry sex. I didn't have a problem with leakage with stimulation for long but my "dry orgasms" were piss fests till a couple months ago. My wife said she didn't mind when it happened inside of her but I think she was just being supportive. That stopped completely a couple of months ago. I also found that switching from Cialis to generic Viaga helped but even better was mixing smaller doses of each together. The problem with Viagra/Sildenafil is your window of opportunity is much smaller. It's almost like you have to schedule sex. They say not to mix them together but I also read that means full doses. I went with that reasoning. Another huge help I found is using one of those little hair elastics like a cock ring. Definitely helps get it up and keep it up! Good luck.

Posts.Title: Seriously Frustrated

Posts.Content: Hi Wishbone, I had the surgery a week after you on Aug. 6. I felt fine after three weeks and was all set to go back to teaching on Aug. 30. But two days before that I was laid out by an infected lymphocele --it felt like Mike Tyson was pounding my midsection-- that put me back in the hospital for five days. I still have a drain in my abdomen that hopefully will come out later this week. I am hoping to return to the classroom on Sept. 28. Here's the thing. I am incredibly fatigued every day now. I don't know if it is the surgery or the infection or that I don't sleep well with the drain in, but I can't imagine being in a back-to-back-to back afternoon classes with 29 seniors, 24 sophomores and 30 seniors. I've loved teaching for the last eight years (I was a journalist most of my life) but I'm actually kind of dreading it now. Teaching is hard, hard work. I have plenty of sick time stored up but I don't want to take more time off. I feel like I'm cheating the kids if I do plus I'm bored out of my mind. I'm hoping once I get the drain out that I can get back to sleeping well. Keep us updated on how your return goes and if anyone else has a story, let's hear it.

Posts.Title: Back to work

Posts.Content: You should talk to your doc about options-- and then find the best urologist/surgeon in your area and get a second opinion. Most insurance companies cover a second opinion completely. You owe it to yourself. This is a major deal and you basically get one chance to get it right. Just like athletes, all the surgeons have huge egos, but just like athletes some are simply more skilled than others. Find the best you can.

Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: I had sex in three weeks, including an orgasm that felt like an air rifle going off (kind of cool). Not very hard, maybe 50 percent, but hard enough with a patient wife. A couple hours later it felt like Mike Tyson hit me in the stomach and i ended up back in the hospital for five days with an infected lymphocele. After that I had a drain in my stomach for 19 days. Docs said the sex didn't cause the lymphocele or infection but that taking it easy might have been the smarter play. Maybe you should have your girlfriend do the work on top. You are healing, after all.

Posts.Title: How soon is too soon for sexual activity after prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Good luck, Gary. My ride home from Boston on Aug. 7, the day after surgery, was about an hour. I didn't have a donut or pillow and didn't need one but you may be different. My aches didn't start until a couple of days later when I noticed my left side, my scrotum and my penis were dark, dark purple and swollen. The bloating/swelling are going down but Ibuprofen is definitely useful. I used the Oxycodone they gave me once but I don't like the drugged feeling i get from that. I also asked them for a script for Adavan because I get wicked claustrophobia at times from things like being on an airplane, MRIs or anesthesia, and having a catheter in. I had the catheter out 7 days after surgery and I have been using Depends Guards and they work fine, better than the CVS brand. I've had very little incontinence in the day and none at night, but at night I wake up every hour feeling like I have to go and I get up and try to go and just pee a little. I haven't got a really good night's sleep yet but other than that I feel great. This is really important: Make sure you use the laxatives and stool softeners they give you too. I had no problem farting or having a BM using them. My brother also had the DaVinci surgery in Boston in 2011 and got a rare something called--phonetic spelling--illyis, which is when your bowels basically forget how to work. They put him back in the hospital for eight more days, fed him intravenously, let him chew ice chips and walk around. When he finally farted they sent him home. He's been fine since. I hope I am and that you are too. I'm not even two weeks out and I am already thinking it wasn't nearly as bad as I feared. If it wasn't so damn hot I'd be chafing at the bit to play golf (which I can't do for two more weeks according to my doc). Good luck.
Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Older brother had DaVinci in 2011 PSA 4.1 at diagnosis (had been up and down in 3s for years) Biopsy at UMass Worcester May 2015. Five of 13 cores positive, three 3+3, one 3+4. one 4+3 No perineural invasion. Da Vinci surgery at Brigham & Women's Boston on Aug. 6, 2015 Nerves taken on left, spared on right Catheter out in 7 days Pathology show tumors on both sides, all reclassified 3+4 Stage T2C NO Focally present tumor on right posterior zone (doc thinks it is nothing) Lymphocele infection on August 29 required five day re-hospitalization and drain insertion. Drain in until Sept. 18 Virtually no incontinence Some ED, switch to sildenafil produced great results. Follow up PSA test on Sept. 9, Dec. 10 and March 5 all <0.02. Test at different clinics on Aug. 26, 2016 0.01, on Feb. 6 2017, <0.01, on July 31, 2017 0.01. "The days my gratitude exceeds my expectations, well, I have really good days" ~ Ray Wylie Hubbard

Posts.Title: My DaVinci date is drawing near

Posts.Content: Radiation can knock the hell out of you but it probably is still after-effects of the infection. I had to get radiation after I had my left nut removed because of testicular cancer in 1989. I had to get 20 days worth to my lymph nodes but they stopped it after 15 treatments because my white blood count went too low (and that makes you feel really tired). They resumed the treatments after a few days. Also, if you get nauseous you may try taking a hit of pot. It works like a charm. I started puking after a few days and they didn't want me to lose any weight because it would move the tattoos. They gave me a pill called Compazine and I threw it up. My doctor told me marijuana would work and he was right. I'd get the radiation after work, go home and take a hit of pot, eat everything not tied down, and play guitar. It was illegal then but the doctors knew it worked.

Posts.Title: Day seven of forty

Posts.Content: You should talk to your doc about options-- and then find the best urologist/surgeon in your area and get a second opinion. Most insurance companies cover a second opinion completely. You owe it to yourself. This is a major deal and you basically get one chance to get it right. Just like athletes, all the surgeons have huge egos, but just like athletes some are simply more skilled than others. Find the best you can.

Posts.Title: Six-week post-op progress report

Posts.Content: Hi Lilguy, I am four months post op and, like oshguy said, it is almost like it never happened. And that's even with a rare complication, an infected lymphocyle, that put me back in the hospital for awhile and put a drain in my stomach for another three weeks. Then i got facial cellulitis which could have been related to my compromised immune system according to the docs. But, like I said, I almost feel now like it never happened. I teach high school English every day and had eight pars in a round of golf last weekend. I have had virtually no incontinence other than an occasional squirt when i sneeze. I never had to wear a pad after one week post catheter and I never really did kegels much. I just posted that I had a PSA test today and I am still in the Zero Club. The only thing that is still a problem is some ED but that is getting better and my wife and I are working with what I get. Good luck, brother.

Posts.Title: PSA Testing Probelms

Posts.Content: When I had daily radiation to my lymph nodes after testicular cancer in 1989 I threw up the pills they gave me. The danger was that if I lost weight the tattoos would move and they would have to stop the treatments till I regained the weight My daughter was being treated for leukemia at the time (she's now a happy and healthy 30 years old) and her Dana Farber/UMass doctor told me I should try taking a hit of pot after each radiation treatment. Worked like a charm! Good luck.

Posts.Title: Stage 4 fun!

Posts.Content: Hi Paddy You can't have too much knowledge. You want to move fast but you also may want to get the opinion of a radiologist and even another experienced surgeon before you make a decision on how to deal with this. Like Highlander said, if your surgeon is not experienced find one who is. They all love to operate so you should have no problem finding someone who is good at it.

Posts.Title: pre opp prostate

Posts.Content: Hi Trinity Definitely talk to a surgeon--and an oncologist and a radiologist. The UMass radiologist I talked to said I should have surgery, not radiation, for a couple of reasons. I went to Boston for a second opinion and Dr. Adam Kibel, the head of urology at Dana Farber agreed surgery was my best option. Your ED will depend on nerve sparing, at least on one side. I got lucky and Dr. Kibel spared the right nerves. Five weeks post op (robotic) I am totally continent (except when I suddenly sneeze I feel a squirt) and I am getting erections, but not great ones. I did have an infection in my gut called a lymphocele that put me back in the hospital for five days (and I still have a drain for it in my belly) but that is a rare surgical (<3 percent) complication and just some bad luck to balance my good luck on the other fronts. I had my operation at Dana Farber/Brigham & Women's in Boston. People go there from all over the world so Rhode Island is not much of a stretch.

Posts.Title: Post op Day 10

Posts.Content: Hello Rad Like Chuck says, it takes time. I had the surgery in August 2015 and it has only been in the last four months or so that I am all the way back. And that is with the aid of generic Viagra (sildenafil). It has been a gradual return to full hardening. The first year was more like a water balloon. I could achieve orgasms after a couple months but now it is like I never had the operation. BTW, I was using Cialis or Viagra for a year or two before the operation. I didn't always need it but I used it as insurance. Did not want to let the little girl down.

Posts.Title: How long after RALP until I can achieve orgasms.

Posts.Content: A lot will depend on luck and your surgeon's skill. I was lucky--my surgeon was able to retain a good urethra stem and I did not have a problem with incontinence after the first couple of weeks. I never really did the kegels that much--at least consciously. I found the pads incredibly uncomfortable and I think I just did a mind over matter thing and decided I was not going to pee in my pants. I always had what they call a "bashful bladder" and would have a hard time peeing on cue, especially in public. I could always stop it mid-stream. It may be that I was doing kegels without trying my whole life.

Posts.Title: Second PSA-test after surgery..

Posts.Content: I bet you have epididymitis. I used to get it occasionally when I was a young man and those sound like the symptoms. I used to get it if I didn't have sex for a long time. In my 30s, that would be more than a couple of days. If you push hard on your epididymis (its a tube leading to your testicles in your scrotum) it will hurt. A urologist can diagnose it in minutes and will prescribe an antibiotic (I believe my doc gave me Cipro) that will get rid of it in a couple of days. Don' worry. There is no way you have prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Terrified That I Have Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Hello all, I'm 63 years old and I just had robotic surgery last Thursday. My doctor at Brigham & Women's in Boston said he took some extra off the top and the left side (including the nerve) but was confident he got it all. I was a Gleason 4+3 and my PSA was 4.1. Dr. Kibel called today to say pathology showed everything was good except for a "positive focal margin" on the right side. He said it was tiny and that it is probably not cancer but just some crap left over from the surgery. He said at this point he would just want to follow it with PSA tests. Needless to say, I heard "positive" louder than anything else he said and my wife and I are now a little worried. I would appreciate hearing from anyone who has dealt with this. I hope I am describing what he said correctly. My urine was pink/red for a while today but my brother (surgery in 2011) said his was too. Now it has changed back to yellow. Catheter is a hassle but keeping the opening clean and using bacitracin makes it bearable. I also ate like a horse today and my puncture wounds are healing up nicely. I haven't had to take any pain meds and I am walking a lot. If it wasn't for this damned focal thing I'd say it was a great day. Actually, I'll say it anyway--I'm still alive.

Posts.Content: Yikes! I had the robotic surgery six days ago in Boston. All is going well --my pee alternates between yellow and pink-- and the catheter is supposed to come out tomorrow My penis and testicle turned dark purple and swelled. I first noticed this yesterday. Today, my penis swelling continues although not my testicle swelling. I know this is pretty graphic but it looks like a buffalo's head is growing behind and beneath the head of penis. It is the size of a ping pong ball. I just put jockey shorts on hoping the support helps--I had not used any support previously and just wore one of my wife's sarongs around the house and even when I walked in the yard. We live in rural part of Central Mass. Is this much swelling normal? Has anyone experienced it?

Posts.Title: Positive focal margin

Posts.Content: There is a third option--radiation. I had radiation after testicular cancer surgery when I was 37 in 1989 (luckily you only need one) so when i found out I had PC last year, the scarring pretty much took standard radiation off the table. Also, the radiologist said the seeds would not work for me because my prostate was too small and any placement would radiate my urethra and that would not be good. My brother had PC in 2011 and had robotic surgery. A year later he had no side effects. I opted for robotic surgery too. I immediately found the best surgeon I could at the best hospital in the Boston area--Adam Kibel, head urologist at Dana Farber Cancer Institute at Brigham & Women's--scheduled the surgery, had it Aug. 6, 2015 and a year later I have no side effects, other than a little ED solved by generic Viagra. I actually had almost no side effects after a couple months. Here's my take on it. I was a journalist most of my life and I am use to digging for information. I found that although open and robotic surgery have about the same success rate, recovery is quicker with robotic. My urologist at UMass, who only did open surgery, was pissed when I went with Dr. Kibel but it's my life, and insurance was going to cover it either way. Go with the best you can find if you go with surgery--the quality of your life depends on it. I think the Mayo Clinic has a great reputation in your neck of the woods. As far as active surveillance, that was not an option for me but I think I would not feel comfortable knowing PC was there. Biopsies also do not sample all of the prostate so there is a chance there is more. Whatever you choose, Wbigs, you'll do fine. As our moderator Chuck likes to point out, Gleason 6 never kills anyone.

Posts.Title: First time here

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Marve;291216]PDV: Already next day out hospital? Here they hold hospital 10 days! So they told. Or maybe you surgery is different than here? I dont know how they make this? Cut stomach or somehow different? I dont know. Yes, Marve, the next day. I had robotic surgery using a DaVinci machine. The robot makes five small incisions in your belly and then pulls the prostate out through the longest one--just a couple inches--near your belly button. I did end up back in the hospital for five days three weeks after my operation because i developed an infected lymphocele. I've had a stomach drain since. I can't wait to get this drain out of my stomach--maybe today! The lymphocele is a rare complication and the odds are your father will not get one. With G6 your dad has a great prognosis and should do fine.

Posts.Title: First time here

Posts.Content: To all the new members or the recently diagnosed, One year ago I was where you are. Actually I was on my way to the golf course when my UMass urologist called to tell me I had prostate cancer. I was not surprised. I knew his nurse would have told me that I didn't if the biopsy was negative so i figured when she said he would call me back it was not good. Plus my older brother had it in 2011. Because my brother was doing fine, and because I had survived testicular cancer when I was 35 and had a benign brain tumor removed when I was 50, I wasn't even that worried. I started to investigate my options and ended up choosing robotic surgery by Dr. Adam Kibel, the head of urology at Dana Farber/Brigham & Women's Hospital. My UMass guy was pissed but, hey, it's my life and I wanted to go with the best. That's an important thing to realize--it's your life, so find the best, most experienced surgeon. I had the surgery in August after a two week trip to Yellowstone with my wife. It went great. Dr. Kibel said he was able to save a good urethra stem and predicted incontinence wouldn't be a problem. He also spared the nerves on one side. I had the catheter out in a week and didn't need a pad after two weeks. I was ready to go back to work--I teach high school English--in three weeks but all of a sudden I got knocked flat by a rare complication, an infected lymphocele. It felt like Mike Tyson punched me in the stomach. That put me back in the hospital for five days and on a stomach drain for two more weeks. They day before I returned to school I played 18 holes and shot an 88. And it's important to note that the lymphocele is extremely rare. Everything since then has been great, so much so that I barely remember the operation and recovery. I still have a bit of ED but thanks to Viagra and an elastic we make it work. I still come on this forum because it was so helpful to me and I want to pay it forward. My message to the newly diagnosed is that the prostate cancer diagnosis may seem like the end of the world but one year later it feels to me like a barely remembered dream.

Posts.Title: Need help- rash from pads

Posts.Content: I'm at the five month mark. Had orgasms after a month or so but Cialis only produced what me and Peachie called "Mr. Softee." Switched to generic Viagra (sidenafil) a couple of weeks ago and much firmer now. Wouldn't call it Mr. Oak, maybe Mr. Willow, but it is definitely harder and long lasting enough for Peachie to get off. I don't know if it is time or the switch to sidenafil or both but Peachie is much happier and I am too. Also, I have finally stopped leaking pee during sex, thank God. The key there is to drain that vein completely before you start.

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Marve;291216]PDV: Already next day out hospital? Here they hold hospital 10 days! So they told. Or maybe you surgery is different than here? I dont know how they make this? Cut stomach or somehow different? I dont know. Yes, Marve, the next day. I had robotic surgery using a DaVinci machine. The robot makes five small incisions in your belly and then pulls the prostate out through the longest one--just a couple inches--near your belly button. I did end up back in the hospital for five days three weeks after my operation because i developed an infected lymphocele. I've had a stomach drain since. I can't wait to get this drain out of my stomach--maybe today! The lymphocele is a rare complication and the odds are your father will not get one. With G6 your dad has a great prognosis and should do fine.

Posts.Title: First time here

Posts.Content: Hello Marve, Your English is better than our Estonian. The doc who did my surgery is also a urologist and surgeon so your dad should be in good hands. I was out of the hospital the next day. I did not have radiation too. I had my PSA tested one month later but I think most wait for two months. Mine was <0.02 (undetectable) which was very good news. My surgeon/urologist is following me. Your dad's Gleason 6 score is the best you could hope for (mine is G3+4+7) and he will be fine. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: Hi Mark, I had the robotic surgery on Aug. 6, less than two weeks ago, and am doing pretty well already. I am planning to go back to teaching when school starts on Sept. 2 and I feel I could already play golf but my doc said to wait for a month. I am having a hard time sleeping for more than an hour or two at a time--which is why I am writing this at 2:30 a.m.-- because I feel the need to urinate constantly at night when I don't really have to. I've been using pads in the day to catch the infrequent leak. My sexy wife and I fooled around a bit last night for the first time and I achieved a half decent erection for a little while. So far, so good on all fronts of recovery. Having the catheter in sucked and I was really bruised and swollen on my left side and my genitals but that is all gone now. Anesthesia knocks the hell out of you and stays in your body for quite a while but little by little it gets better every day. My brother had the surgery in 2011 and had a couple of problems but even with that he was back to work and on the links in a couple of months. Hang in there, brother. This forum is a godsend. I've used it often and got great info and reassurance from guys who have been down this road already.

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: I can vouch for what Michigan Man 16 says. I used his pharmacy in Michigan and got 90 tabs of 20mg sildenafil for 55 bucks. I was on Cialis before and sildenafil definitely works better for me. They are legit--you have to have your doc call in a prescription--and fast. I got my pills in the mail in 3 days. BTW, I was getting Cialis for next to nothing because a friend of mine, a fellow PC survivor, got his insurance company to pay for it. Mine wouldn't and it would have been prohibitively expensive. Plus it didn't work great for me. Prescription Viagra was even more expensive. I called CVS and asked how much it would be for 10 tabs of 100mg and they said 480 buck--48 bucks a piece! Go with MM16's advice. It's the LUEA pharmacy in Swartz Creek, MI.

Posts.Title: Post op Day 10

Posts.Content: I've been really lucky as far as recovery from surgery goes. I was ready to play golf and go back to work after three weeks. Other than a little squirt when I sneeze I have had no problems with incontinence since Day 1. ED is getting better bit by bit. My first post op problem was an infected lymphocele caused by leaking lymph nodes. At three weeks, it hit me like a Mike Tyson punch and put me back in he hospital for five days. Then I had a stomach drain for three more weeks. I finally had that removed on Sept. 25 and returned to work on Sept. 28. While at work (I teach in a high school) my nose started to hurt and turn purple. I went to my primary care guy that day. He took one look at me and sent me to the ER. "You have facial cellulitis," he said. Five hours later, I went home after promising to return to the hospital every day for up to two weeks for IV antibiotics. Every day after school I would drive to the hospital in Worcester for a half hour IV. I had the IV port removed on Oct. 7 and played in a golf tournament with my brother and a gig with my band. Last Friday, a purple spot appeared on my nose again. Now I'm back on IV antibiotics. This is all related to surgery and lymph nodes and I have to say it sucks. Worse, my daughter in law, the mother of my 6 and 3 year old grandkids, just got diagnosed with uterine cancer. Has anyone else on this forum ever dealt with post-op cellulitis?

Posts.Title: Cellulitis

Posts.Content: With 3+3 Gleason you may be a candidate for active surveillance but you need to stay on top of it. I had the Da Vinci surgery seven months ago and feel I am 100 percent back to normal. You need to talk to good doctors--oncologists, urologists, radiologists etc. -- about your situation because every PC case is unique. Whatever your decision is you'll be fine. My Gleason is 3+4 but when I had a biopsy they thought one core was 4+3. I asked my urologist what would happen if I didn't do anything. He said,"You'll probably live 10 years but the last five would suck." I got a second opinion and that doctor concurred.

Posts.Title: Have PC

Posts.Content: With 3+3 Gleason you may be a candidate for active surveillance but you need to stay on top of it. I had the Da Vinci surgery seven months ago and feel I am 100 percent back to normal. You need to talk to good doctors--oncologists, urologists, radiologists etc. -- about your situation because every PC case is unique. Whatever your decision is you'll be fine. My Gleason is 3+4 but when I had a biopsy they thought one core was 4+3. I asked my urologist what would happen if I didn't do anything. He said,"You'll probably live 10 years but the last five would suck." I got a second opinion and that doctor concurred.

Posts.Title: New to the Forum

Posts.Content: I bet you have epididymitis. I used to get it occasionally when I was a young man and those sound like the symptoms. I used to get it if I didn't have sex for a long time. In my 30s, that would be more than a couple of days. If you push hard on your epididymis (its a tube leading to your testicles in your scrotum) it will hurt. A urologist can diagnose it in minutes and will prescribe an antibiotic (I believe my doc gave me Cipro) that will get rid of it in a couple of days. Don' worry. There is no way you have prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Terrified That I Have Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks Mike G. I am getting my catheter pulled tomorrow. Can't wait. I only worry about the focal point margin when I think about it. Mostly, I'm thinking about the arrangement my band will use on "I want you Back" when we play a wedding in November.
Posts.Title: Positive focal margin

Posts.Content: Hello all, I'm 63 years old and I just had robotic surgery last Thursday. My doctor at Brigham & Women's in Boston said he took some extra off the top and the left side (including the nerve) but was confident he got it all. I was a Gleason 4+3 and my PSA was 4.1. Dr. Kibel called today to say pathology showed everything was good except for a "positive focal margin" on the right side. He said it was tiny and that it is probably not cancer but just some crap left over from the surgery. He said at this point he would just want to follow it with PSA tests. Needless to say, I heard "positive" louder than anything else he said and my wife and I are now a little worried. I would appreciate hearing from anyone who has dealt with this. I hope I am describing what he said correctly. My urine was pink/red for a while today but my brother (surgery in 2011) said his was too. Now it has changed back to yellow. Catheter is a hassle but keeping the opening clean and using bacitracin makes it bearable. I also ate like a horse today and my puncture wounds are healing up nicely. I haven't had to take any pain meds and I am walking a lot. If it wasn't for this damned focal thing I'd say it was a great day. Actually, I'll say it anyway--I'm still alive.
Posts.Title: Positive focal margin

Posts.Content: Yikes! I had the robotic surgery six days ago in Boston. All is going well --my pee alternates between yellow and pink-- and the catheter is supposed to come out tomorrow My penis and testicle turned dark purple and swelled. I first noticed this yesterday. Today, my penis swelling continues although not my testicle swelling. I know this is pretty graphic but it looks like a buffalo's head is growing behind and beneath the head of penis. It is the size of a ping pong ball. I just put jockey shorts on hoping the support helps--I had not used any support previously and just wore one of my wife's sarongs around the house and even when I walked in the yard. We live in rural part of Central Mass. Is this much swelling normal? Has anyone experienced it?

Posts.Title: One day after surgery.

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Marve;291216]PDV: Already next day out hospital? Here they hold hospital 10 days! So they told. Or maybe you surgery is different than here? I dont know how they make this? Cut stomach or somehow different? I dont know. Yes, Marve, the next day. I had robotic surgery using a DaVinci machine. The robot makes five small incisions in your belly and then pulls the prostate out through the longest one--just a couple inches--near your belly button. I did end up back in the hospital for five days three weeks after my operation because i developed an infected lymphocele. I've had a stomach drain since. I can't wait to get this drain out of my stomach--maybe today! The lymphocele is a rare complication and the odds are your father will not get one. With G6 your dad has a great prognosis and should do fine.

Posts.Title: First time here

Posts.Content: Thanks all. I just got back from second IV treatment. This one was much easier--just a half hour-- and the doc said if the cellulitis clears significantly by Thursday she'll switch me to oral antibiotics. Also, I am not sure any of this has to do with me trying to be too active too soon. We all have staph and other germs on our skin and some apparently got into my belly to explain the lymphocele. Or maybe Da Vinci didn't wash his hands after a trip to the robot restroom. The dust in my nose may be the cause of the cellulitis but it's not like I was pushing a an old powerless mower. I was riding on a John Deere tractor, listening to tunes on my headphones and drinking a Sam Adams. Other than looking like WC Fields, I feel fine.

Posts.Title: One day after surgery.

Posts.Content: Hello Marve, Your English is better than our Estonian. The doc who did my surgery is also a urologist and surgeon so your dad should be in good hands. I was out of the hospital the next day. I did not have radiation too. I had my PSA tested one month later but I think most wait for two months. Mine was <0.02 (undetectable) which was very good news. My surgeon/urologist is following me. Your dad's Gleason 6 score is the best you could hope for (mine is G3+4+7) and he will be fine. Good luck.

Posts.Title: One day after surgery.

Posts.Content: Hello Marve, Your English is better than our Estonian. The doc who did my surgery is also a urologist and surgeon so your dad should be in good hands. I was out of the hospital the next day. I did not have radiation too. I had my PSA tested one month later but I think most wait for two months. Mine was <0.02 (undetectable) which was very good news. My surgeon/urologist is following me. Your dad's Gleason 6 score is the best you could hope for (mine is G3+4+7) and he will be fine. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: Well, I finally went back to teaching yesterday. It was 52 days after my Da Vinci surgery. I was ready to go back on Aug. 31, the first day of school, but on the Saturday before I was laid low by an infected lymphocele and ended up back in the hospital for five days and with a drain in my gut for 19 days. The week before I went back I felt great--even shot an 86 in golf On Sept. 24, I mowed our big lawn. We are in the middle of a severe drought here and i got a lot of dust in my nose. On Friday I developed a pimple just inside my right nostril. By Saturday the outside of my nose became purple and it continued to spread. I tried to relieve it by popping it to no avail. My wife and I went out to eat and I was freezing although no one else in the restaurant was. When I returned to my school all the kids were excited and my fellow teachers were great. The day went well except my nose--which now made me look like WC Fields-- started killing me. I went to my family doctor and he took one look and said, "you have cellulitis" and added because it was on my face, I needed to go to an emergency room in Worcester for IV antibiotics. I did--and three hours later I got them. It was five hours by the time I left the hospital . They wanted to admit me but I begged them to let me go home. I just hate being in hospitals. They relented and said I could go if I committed to returning every day for two weeks for more IV antibiotics. I had to call in sick to school to do today's appointment. My nose still looks like Rudolph's but it doesn't hurt today. My family doctor said he thought the cellulitis was just a bad luck coincidence. One of the docs at St. Vincent said it could be related to my post-op infection because my immune system has been weakened. All I know is this is getting really old. I have been really lucky so far with the prostate surgery itself. My followup PSA was <.02. I had little pain and recovery was fast. The ED is getting better a little. I am totally continent during the day and don't even wear pads. I now generally only have to get up twice at night. I urinated in my bed on the seventh day after surgery but had no problem again like that till last night when I peed the bed again. I figure it had to be all the fluid they poured in my through the IV. Yesterday was not my day. Hopefully, today will be better.

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: Hi Ocho Ocho, I am the same age as you and I have survived both testicular cancer in 1989 and prostate cancer this past year. Neither presented with any testicular pain. In between I had epididymitis several times which did cause pain in my remaining nut (actually it is the little tube leading to it) and each time antibiotics got rid of it. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: Felt great Saturday and probably pushed. Swelling and pain increased throughout afternoon. Local hospital transferred me to Boston. Urinary tract infection and something called limphecile or something like that. In till tomorrow at least
Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: I'm at the five month mark. Had orgasms after a month or so but Cialis only produced what me and Peachie called "Mr. Softee." Switched to generic Viagra (sidenafil) a couple of weeks ago and much firmer now. Wouldn't call it Mr. Oak, maybe Mr. Willow, but it is definitely harder and long lasting enough for Peachie to get off. I don't know if it is time or the switch to sidenafil or both but Peachie is much happier and I am too. Also, I have finally stopped leaking pee during sex, thank God. The key there is to drain that vein completely before you start.

Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: My family doc said he thought it was just a coincidence that I got both. A doc in the ER said he thinks my immune system was knocked for a loop by the infected lymphocele. making it possible for the cellulitis to start. The PA who works with my surgeon said the lymphocele infection was caused by staph that almost invariably gets into a person during surgery. The infectious disease specialist who has been treating me for cellulitis said she doesn't know if they have anything to do with each other although staph is definitely the problem. She kind of took the fun out of the IV removal today by saying that I will probably get cellulitis again. My wife and I went out for blackened haddock fajitas and a pitcher of margaritas tonight. It's Tuesday but I don't want to chance waiting for the weekend.

Posts.Title: Cellulitis

Posts.Content: Maybe the most important advice of all--get laid as often as possible. It will probably work again but may take a while--14 months in my case before it was back to normal. Also, once you have the surgery take laxatives and stool softener. My brother who had the surgery four year before me, wound up back in the hospital for a week and they wouldn't let him eat or leave till he passed gas. They fed him through an IV and all he could do was walk up and down the aisles.

Posts.Content: Hi Badman I've used LUEA pharmacy in Swartz Creek,MI with great satisfaction. I too have no help from my insurance company. I get generic Viagra but I bet they have generic Cialis too. I get 20 mg Sildenafil since that is the only dose they carry and I take five at a time. I get 90 pills for $63 including shipping. I call it generic Viagra because sildenafil is the active ingredient in Viagra. It works better for me than Cialis. The number for Luea is 810-635-3355. You can call and ask them questions but your doc needs to call in a prescription before you can order.

Posts.Title: Generic Cialis?

Posts.Content: Trinity, Why would you not get a complete second opinion? I believe most insurances pay for it. Since you are in Rhode Island it is a short drive to Boston to the world renown Dana Farber Clinic or many of the other great hospitals there. I was diagnosed in Worcester at UMass, which is a wonderful hospital, and consulted with an oncologist and radiologist as well as a urologist there. But I also immediately did some research and made an appointment with Dr. Adam Kibel, the head of urology at Dana Farber/Brigham & Women's. He reviewed my slides from UMAss as did a Dana Farber pathologist. They also reviewed my MRI and Dr. Kibel ordered some additional tests. The doc at UMass did not do robotic surgery and that is what my wife and I decided we wanted so we went with Dr. Kibel. I feel we made a fully informed decision. It is your life, you should do the same.

Five of 13 cores positive, three 3+3, one 3+4. one 4+3 No perineural invasion. Da Vinci surgery at Brigham & Women's Boston on Aug. 6, 2015 Nerves taken on left, spared on right Catheter out in 7 days Pathology show tumors on both sides, all reclassified 3+4 Stage T2C NO Focally present tumor on right posterior zone (doc thinks it is nothing) Lymphocele infection on August 29 required five day re-hospitalization and drain insertion. Drain in until Sept. 18 Virtually no incontinence Some ED, switch to sildenafil produced great results. Follow up PSA test on Sept. 9, Dec. 10 and March 5 all <0.02. Test at different clinics on Aug. 26, 2016 0.01, on Feb. 6 2017, <0.01, on July 31, 2017 0.01. "The days my gratitude exceeds my expectations, well, I have really good days" ~ Ray Wylie Hubbard

Posts.Title: Checking in after successful surgery

Posts.Content: Trinity, Why would you not get a complete second opinion? I believe most insurances pay for it. Since you are in Rhode Island it is a short drive to Boston to the world renown Dana Farber Clinic or many of the other great hospitals there. I was diagnosed in Worcester at UMass, which is a wonderful hospital, and consulted with an oncologist and radiologist as well as a urologist there. But I also immediately did some research and made an appointment with Dr. Adam Kibel, the head of urology at Dana Farber/Brigham & Women's. He reviewed my slides from UMAss as did a Dana Farber pathologist. They also reviewed my MRI and Dr. Kibel ordered some additional tests. The doc at UMass did not do robotic surgery and that is what my wife and I decided we wanted so we went with Dr. Kibel. I feel we made a fully informed decision. It is your life, you should do the same.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Consult Question

Posts.Content: The skill of the surgeon is tantamount. Make sure you ask your potential docs how many time they have done the surgery. The robotic learning curve is steep and you don't want to put a rookie in at QB.

Posts.Title: Any opinions using Kaiser Santa Clara (SF) for robotic radical prostatectomy ?

Posts.Content: The setbacks do suck but the important thing is the progress. I've had virtually no incontinence since Day 1 except for A. sneezing and B. I peed in my bed twice. I can avoid the squirt if I quickly kegel when I feel a sneeze coming on but if the sneeze is sudden a little drop escapes. The first time I peed in the bed was right after the catheter came out. The second time was this week after I had a two-hour IV for antibiotics for facial cellulitis. (The cellulitis may or may not be related to the infected lymphocele I developed three weeks after surgery--a whole 'nother story.) One great step forward I've had recently is for weeks I had to get up every two hours to pee. Now I only get up once during the night, piss like Man O War, and then go back to sleep. That is a beautiful thing. I can't wait to write my name in the snow this winter. Actually, after the winter we had here in New England last year, I can wait.

Posts.Title: Incontinence Progress

Posts.Content: Hi MB, I had a PSA that went up and down for years but I kept putting off a biopsy because my brother, who had PC in 2011, told me it hurt like hell. Last spring, my primary care doc and then a urologist felt a bump on DREs. I then went with their recommendation for a biopsy. It wasn't bad at all, more an annoyance than a pain and I walked 18 holes the next day. The biopsy consisted of 13 samples--the standard 12 and an extras one on the bump. Five came back positive but the bump wasn't one of them. I had the robotic surgery in August and am 100 percent back to normal now, other than a little ED sometimes. Don't worry till you have to and even then know you'll be fine.

My ED is worse than yours but I'm a lot older. The pills work but I'll never be 18 again.

Posts.Title: 3 months after da Vinci...first post op PSA

Posts.Content: I'm not sure there is a lot of difference. I tried both recreationally for the last couple years before my surgery, mainly as insurance and to get really hard. They both worked well and the Cialis worked for days--waking up with a giant erection at 4 a.m. for the next two nights was standard and a real pain. Now I'm three and a half months post op--doc took all the nerves on one side-- and fighting with my insurance company over a Cialis prescription. I have still been using it through the generosity of a friend who has a prescription for 30 pills of 20 mg per month. No one in their 60s gets laid that often so he gives me some. It hasn't worked great. I get hard enough for penetration but nothing to write to a porn movie producer about. There are signs it is getting better. I hope it does because my beautiful,wild and much younger wife is talking about dating--a tease which always worked better than Cialis or Viagra in the past.

Posts.Title: Viagra versus Cialis questions

Posts.Content: I posted this on Facebook Jan. 1 but it is even more appropriate here. Happy 2016. A lot of people had asked me if Id be glad when 2015 is over. In August I had prostate cancer surgery, followed by an infection that kept me out of school for a month. Then my daughter in law was diagnosed with uterine cancer. Then I had cellulitis which required daily IV antibiotics. Then our beloved dog Yaz died. But, you know what? I still kind of liked 2015. As the late great Jimmy McNally would say, Any day on this side of the grass is a good one. The older I get, the more I see the glass half full. Some might think my 2015 resembled Norm MacDonalds finger licking career. I even found myself in November saying I couldnt wait till 2015 was over. But then I spent the week before Christmas playing music with my Clinton High students and the night after Christmas I played with my band at my buddy Kokess Black Sheep. The band, with my in-thepocket son on drums, was rocking. At one point I looked out and my two amazing daughters and my wonderful daughter in law were dancing together. My beautiful wife and my beautiful ex-wife were dancing together. Damn, I must have done something right. Once again in 2015 my brother and I didnt win the Scituate CC Ringer, but, the important thing is, I got to play golf with my brother again. And I get to spend every school day with 120 wonderful young people. We read great books together, sing together and laugh together. Sometimes a little education for all of us actually slips through. I show my students video clips of my grandkids sometimes. I tell them that it took me nine years to finish college, that Ive been down and out as often as Ive been at the top of the mountain, and that Ive never made a lot of money. I wish you my kind of success. Thats what I tell them, just what Dicky Fox, the old guy, tells Jerry MaGuire. I love my wife. I love my life. I wish you my kind of success  I wish it for all of you too. Happy New Years everyone.

Posts.Title: Got 8 week post surgery follow-up and first PSA score today.....

Posts.Content: Hi Alan Welcome, unfortunately. This forum is a great source of information and camaraderie. The good news is that you are not going to die. The bad news is the treatment is going to disrupt your life for awhile. I had the robotic surgery on Aug. 6 and I was all set to go back to teaching and playing golf on Aug. 30. Unfortunately I had a somewhat rare complication (an infected lymphocele) and that has set me back a few weeks, but again, that complication is rare. I also got a great report from my surgeon yesterday--no PSA now and, like he said, PSA is the smoke of prostate cancer. If there's no smoke, there's no fire. I don't have too much advice for you. Others on this forum know way more that I do, but I will say to definitely get a second opinion. Insurance will pay for it. Also, meet with an oncologist, radiologist etc. and explore your options You have plenty of time. The cancer you have has been growing for years and a few months now won't make a difference. And stay up--like one of my daughters said when I told her, "that's a good kind of cancer, right."

Posts.Title: Just learned my biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: As you can see from my signature I too was a 7. Fifteen months post op now and it is like it never happened--and that included a month dealing with an incredibly rare surgical side effect. My brother--a 2011 DaVinci veteran-- and I even won a golf tournament last month. Full continence came almost immediately (not the case for everyone). The ED took longer for me but now ol Memo the Trouser Monster is back to fully stiff with the aid of generic Viagra. The dry orgasms are just as good as the old ones. Most importantly my PSA is undetectable. The best advice you will get on this forum is to make sure the surgeon you choose is experienced and good at what he does. This is your life and not all surgeons are the same. They all want to operate just like all quarterbacks want to play, but there aren't many Tom Bradys. Find the best you can. Good luck. I hope you have as good a trip as I've had.

Posts.Title: PSA Time

Posts.Content: When I say "second opinion" I am talking beyond reviewing the biopsy report. The surgeons all have big egos and they all want to operate. The doctor at UMass who diagnosed me wanted to do open surgery. He said he never leaned robotic, which has a steep learning curve. He insisted there was no difference in outcome or recovery time. I then met with a UMass oncologist and UMass radiologist. The radiologist said radiation was not a great option for me for a couple of reasons--previous radiation in the pelvic area and my prostate was too small. When pressed subsequently, the radiologist said, off the record, that he would recommend a different surgeon. In the meantime, I had read several papers that said recovery time is shorter with robotic. Having been a newspaper reporter for most of my life, I was used to asking tough questions and used to finding the foremost experts on subjects. (An example would be when my daughter had leukemia as a toddler. We had to make a decision on using radiation to her head, which would possibly drop her IQ 80 points. I called the head of the National Cancer Institute and the head of the renowned Dana Farber Clinic. They disagreed with each other completely. We ended up deciding again radiation and today my daughter is a happy. healthy and brilliant 29 year old.) In Boston we are blessed with the some of the finest hospitals in the world. I made an appointment with Dr. Adam Kibel, head of urology at Dana Farber. My wife and I interviewed him and felt the most comfortable with him and with his vast experience with robotics. My UMass urologist got all pissy when I told him of my decision and he later left me a long message on my cell phone basically saying he didn't want me as a patient anymore. Good. I needed to do what is best for me. Alan, you do too. Be your own advocate. It is your life. Read. Investigate. Interview.

Posts.Title: Just learned my biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Hi Sky I'm about 70 days post op. Incontinence has not been a big problem since the first week except when I sneeze and if I feel the sneeze coming on I can do a kegel to block the squirt. I too lost the nerves on one side. I had an orgasm with Mr. Softee early on. I still don't get real hard but my wife (a mere 15 years younger) and I are making it work. I did notice the firmness is starting to increase a bit, aided by 10 mg of Cialis. My insurance company won't pay for it either but I have a friend on a different health plan who gets 30 day supplies of 20 mg for $3 a pop. Nobody screws that much so he sells me the surplus. The one thing that does suck is that when I have an orgasm, some urine comes out. I know other people have written that happened to them but I was hoping it would stop by now. One time when I was, ahem, practicing alone, a lot came out. My wife says that doesn't bother her but I can't imagine it is good for her.

Posts.Title: PSA Time

Posts.Content: Hi Sky I'm about 70 days post op. Incontinence has not been a big problem since the first week except when I sneeze and if I feel the sneeze coming on I can do a kegel to block the squirt. I too lost the nerves on one side. I had an orgasm with Mr. Softee early on. I still don't get real hard but my wife (a mere 15 years younger) and I are making it work. I did notice the firmness is starting to increase a bit, aided by 10 mg of Cialis. My insurance company won't pay for it either but I have a friend on a different health plan who gets 30 day supplies of 20 mg for $3 a pop. Nobody screws that much so he sells me the surplus. The one thing that does suck is that when I have an orgasm, some urine comes out. I know other people have written that happened to them but I was hoping it would stop by now. One time when I was, ahem, practicing alone, a lot came out. My wife says that doesn't bother her but I can't imagine it is good for her.

Posts.Title: PSA Time

Posts.Content: Hi Oshguy I had the Davinci a month before you. We have a similar pathology but had a bit opposite experience regarding incontinence and ED. I've had virtually no incontinence but I did have ED issues. It would get as big as always but would not be very firm.This is getting better since I switched from Cialis to generic Viagra (sildenafil). Also I find if I empty my bladder completely before sex I now avoid the leakage problem. That is just recently so you should be there soon. I had a post-surgery complication with an infection that set me back a month but I also feel completely back to normal energy-wise. I've had two PSA test since surgery and both were <0.02.

Posts.Title: Newbe - 66 Days post op Da Vinci

Posts.Content: I'm just throwing this out to see what the brothers say. I had the surgery two weeks ago and feel great. I was just dancing to Creedence blasting in my living room (no one else home). I picked tomatoes and peppers in my garden and made a nice marinara sauce today. I drove my Ford 150--and felt a tiny squirt whenever I shifted-- to the school I teach at to pick up some books for the upcoming semester. I bought my co-teacher a bag of apples from our tree. It weighed more than 10 pounds but was not a strain at all. I'd love to play golf. My doc said a month for golf before the surgery but I've seen posts somewhere where people said they played in three weeks. What is everyone's experience? What is the danger? Of course, I will clear it with my surgeon first but I'd be interested to know if other people hit the links in three weeks.

Posts.Title: Golf?

Posts.Content: Hi PCWIF3 I'm glad it wasn't what I had. Twenty four days after my surgery I had an infected lymphocele and ended up back in the hospital for five days and with a drain in my gut for 19. It sounds like your husband is something else. My urine was not dark. The infected lymph node fluid was, but that was not in my bladder, it was in the lymphocele. The lymphocele shows up on a CT scan. Did they do one of those?

Posts.Content: Hello all, I've mentioned this in other threads but I have not got a lot of feedback. A couple weeks ago, three weeks post surgery, I was laid low by excruciating pain in my abdomen. I spent five days in the hospital diagnosed with an infected lymphocele. I have a drain in my stomach now and it will probably be there for at least a couple more weeks. Unless I misheard them, my surgery team indicated this is fairly common but the more I read online the less common I think it is. Has anyone else on this forum ever had one?

Posts.Title: Golf?

Posts.Content: Still draining mine. It was putting out 600 to 1200 CCs a day at first, now it is down below 100. They want it below 10 CCs a day before they remove the drain. I have a CT scan scheduled for Monday. If it is down low enough and the scan is good they'll pull the drain. Thank God. This complication has been harder for me than the recovery from surgery. Lots of fatigue and frustration.
